If so, why is the minister, together with his colleague Senator Hill, who is jointly responsible for the Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program, shirking accountability by, firstly, refusing to identify the 16 projects which failed to meet the assessment benchmark of 15 points and, secondly, withholding from public scrutiny the reasons why they chose to ignore departmental advice in relation to these 16 projects?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI think the Prime Minister was quite correct. What he was saying was that, at the end of the day, you do not slavishly follow the advice you get from the bureaucracy. As I understand it, that is the Labor Party's position as well. In other words, if you call for advice, that is what you get. But, at the end of the day, you make up your mind. If you say, `I am going to delegate'âin other words, vacate the field, do a Senator Faulkner and say, `I'm not interested. I'll be busy playing politics back home in New South Wales and I will go along with what ever the bureaucracy says'âthat is a different approach to ours. If the Labor Party takes the view that we should identify certain projects simply because of its prurient political interest in the subject, that is not a sufficient reason. What we are obliged to do is to provide proper reasons for the decisions we takeâand we didâand to choose the best projects. The Labor Party, the opposition, knows as well as I do that it has been given every opportunity on a number of occasions to point to any single project that it regards as not deserving of our support. The mere fact that there is disagreement between the bureaucratsâand remember that there was a joint task force of both Senator Hill's department and mine offering advice at one levelâ
âWhich you ignored.
âYou just want to throw these epithets around. You say that if you take advice on board, you consider it and reject it, that is ignoring. That is what you say, isn't it?
âWhere are your reasons?
âOrder! Senator Alston is answering Senator Cook's question. Senator Faulkner, you ought not to be interrupting in the way that you are.

âThat is the essential difference, that we chose to exercise the discretion that was vested in us. We took a good look at all of these projectsâand there were some hundreds of themâand we made a judgment. Is the Labor Party seriously saying that we should not have done that, that we should have followed the advice of the bureaucrats? I was simply pointing out, Madam President, before you correctly told Senator Faulkner to pull his head in, that we had conflicting advice on some projectsâin other words, the Centenary of Federation advice differed in some respects from the advice from the joint task force. Again, that simply highlights that people of good will can disagree on these matters. At the end of the day, we were charged with making judgments, and we did, and we have nothing to apologise for in that regard. I think you will find that all the recipients of those policies would share the same view. If you want to point to any of those projects that you say should not have been funded, I would be delighted to hear from you.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I have not had an answer to two parts of my question. The first concerned the refusal to identify the 16 projects which failed to meet the assessment benchmark of 15 points. Minister, can you say why you have refused to do that? If you believe you have not refused to do that, when and where did you do that? And be honest and straightforward about that. The second part of the question referred to withholding from public scrutiny the reasons why they chose to ignore departmental advice in relation to these 16 projects. Why are you withholding from public scrutiny the reasons for ignoring departmental advice on these 16 projects? Will you give us an explanation on that point as well?
âSenator, your question should be asked to the chair, not directly across to the minister, and the answer also should be directed the same way.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âYes, Madam President, and I take it that I can ignore the gratuitous abuse and advice that I got in that question. Madam President, Senator Hill quite rightly pointed out that these matters were very carefully considered. We gave the reasons that we were required to give.
âWhen?
âWe gave reasons for them. You think that therefore, if cabinet comes to a decision and has reasons for that, you can argue that somehow that should be in the public arena?
âYes. That's what the Auditor-General says.
âThat is what you say, that cabinet decisionsâ

answer.para: Senator Faulkner interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Faulkner!

âOne cannot help those who cannot help themselves, Madam President. If Senator Faulkner is seriously saying for the public record that he believes that cabinet decisions should be made available because the opposition would like them to be on the record, that is a preposterous proposal.

answer.para: Senator Faulkner interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Faulkner, don't interrupt.

âThe fact is, those projects did not fail to meet assessment benchmarks. They did not, as Senator Faulkner has tried to peddle in the media, fail to meet minimum criteria. They simply got point scores, which we took into account in making the judgments we did. (Time expired)

âOn a point of order, Madam President: I ask you to consider under standing order 203(e), I think it is, your capacity to bring Senator Faulkner into line as a serial wrecker of the Senate. I raise this because, in the answer that was just given, twice you directly called Senator Faulkner to order, as you frequently do, and rightly soâI am sure you have everybody's support in doing so. After calling him to order he simply continued, which is, of course, why you had to call him to order the second time. The only reason you did not have to call him to order a third time is that the time for the answer expired.

interjection.para: Madam President, under that standing order I ask you to consider what you can do about people who serially wreck, and I ask you to consider it not on the basis of what he has done today but on the basis that he is a permanent serial wrecker of time in the Senate.

talk.start.para: âOn the point of order, Madam President: I also ask you take into account, as you rule on that point of order, the fact that Senator Alston cannot answer these questions, being protected by, of all people, Senator Vanstone, to waste more time in question time. Let's get on with it and get this minister to answer the questions that are properly directed to him.
âI shall look at the matters that have been raised.

âMy question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Robert Hill. Minister, are you aware that last Saturday in Wattle Block near Northcliffe in the south-west of Western Australia, a group of 40 men, armed with baseball bats, axes and sledgehammers and masked with balaclavas, ransacked and burned a forest conservations' camp and threatened to kill the forest protesters? Are you further aware that your colleague Mr Wilson Tuckey addressed an angry group of pro-logging protesters outside the WA Parliament House only the day before, inciting them to levels of violence, where he was quoted as saying, `These people down there do not see Richard Court keeping the law, so why should they?' Does your government endorse these words of Mr Tuckey? If not, what will the Prime Minister do to reprimand him for his appalling behaviour?
âOn a point of order, Madam President: the questioner clearly reflected on the minister in suggesting that he had incited violence. An allegation of that description clearly ought to be withdrawn.
âAn imputation of that sort ought not be made against a member of this chamber or a member of the other chamber. I would ask for that to be eliminated from the question.

âI thank the honourable senator for the question. Certainly, I saw the public reports of violence in the forests in south-west Western Australia and I deplore violence of that kind. In fact, I deplore violence in any circumstances. In relation to Mr Tuckey, the reports I saw were that he had made the point that in fact the atmosphere was extremely heated. I cannot see how he can be condemned for bringing that to the attention of interested parties, in particular the authorities. I saw nothing that suggested that Mr Tuckey was in any way inciting that violence.

answer.para: We have made an effort to settle forest issues in a way that can give good conservation outcomes and provide resource security for the forest industry. We believe we have done so reasonably successfully in Tasmania and in Victoria. I think there is a further announcement being made on Victoria today. If it is made in the terms that I understand it will be, it will be further good news. We believe also that we achieved a good negotiated outcome in Western Australia. It was a disappointment to us that the management practices were subsequently unilaterally changed by the Western Australian government. But be that as it may, and notwithstanding the obvious disappointment of some parties in the heated environment, that in no way can justify violence. I certainly implore all those concerned to recognise that violence will never solve issues of this type or any other type and to work with the Western Australian government in a constructive and positive way in the implementation of the forest management processes they are adopting.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister: will he be calling upon Mr Tuckey to apologise for the provocative role that he played in this incident? Further, will the government accept any responsibility for and contribute towards the financial restitution of the damages incurred?

âAs I said to the honourable senator, what was reported and what I picked up of what Mr Tuckey said was not provocative. In fact, it was a statement of fact that the environment is extremely heated. You could applaud Mr Tuckey for drawing that to the attention of the parties. I cannot see how in any way you can blame Mr Tuckey for that heated circumstance. In relation to restitution, I cannot see how that should be the responsibility of this government.

subdebateinfo.title: Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Alston, Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. Does the minister accept that what is at issue in relation to the government's administration of the $70 million FCHP Program is not the worthiness or otherwise of the 60 successful projects but the basis on which, on the eve of a federal election, the government chose to ignore the outcome of a rigorous and exhaustive assessment process in respect of 16 of the 60 successful projects? Does the minister accept that, where ministers choose to exercise their discretion in a way which is contrary to departmental advice, particularly in relation to discretionary grants programs, it is incumbent on ministers to explain why? Why won't the minister release the reasons why he and Senator Hill decided to fund 16 projects that did not meet the minimum benchmark that was recommended by their own departments?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI am not sure where you start or finish pointing out the inadequacies and inaccuracies that Senator Faulkner wants to try and get up in the public arena on this issue. He chooses to say that the worthiness of these projects is not a major issueâin other words, $70 million worth of projectsâand that `I do not really care at the end of the day whether they are good or bad projects; I just want to know that you have published reasons.' That is what the Labor Party say. In other words, they say, `We are not interested in outcomes.' That is what he is sayingâ`We are not interested in outcomes; we simply want to know as much as we can possibly get because we think there might be some political advantage to us.'

answer.para: Let us be perfectly plain about what Senator Faulkner is about in this exercise. He has just conceded that the merits of the projects are irrelevant. They were not to us; that is why we exercised our discretion. That is not the same as ignoring outcomes; it is the very opposite. We were at all times concerned to ensure the best outcomes. We did not ignore the advice we got; we took it into account. We did not act contrary to advice, any more than those opposite act contrary to advice when someone suggests you do something. We have given you a lot of free advice over the years; you are free to accept or reject that. Others might give you contrary advice. Your task is to choose. And that is exactly what we did.

To say it is incumbent upon us to explain why is simply code for saying that the Labor Party are absolutely bankruptâhad no idea what they were going to run with this week. Because they think they have got one journalist in the press gallery who is interested in the subject, they think they might as well give it another run to disguise the fact that there really is not anything else around. The economy is in good shape. You are industrial relations bankrupt. You have no alternative policies, so you have to find something like this.
We did not act contrary to anything; we did not have a set of minimum criteria which were not achieved. We simply got a points score put along projects, and we chose the best ones.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Isn't it true that ministers agreed to the assessment guidelines and procedures that were developed by departments on 9 July 1998? If so, why did the minister and his colleague Senator Hill decide to overturn the process and ignore its outcomes in relation to 16, or more than 25 per cent, of the 60 successful projects? If the minister and you, Senator Alston, are so confident about your own counselâthat it is superior to that of the two departments concernedâin relation to the 16 projects, why don't you submit reasonsâyour reasons, the reasons of you and Senator Hillâfor public scrutiny? Front up with the reasons for overturning your department's advice.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThese are just more pejorative expressions, Madam President. `Overturning advice'? If, every time you made your own judgment, you were overturning departmental advice I suspect the department would not have been terribly impressed. They would have said, `We offer you this advice in good faith. Take it on board; accept it or reject it. Don't treat us as though somehow you are rejecting our advice, because you are not.'

answer.para: The question suggested that somehow there had been no guidelines or procedures which we had decided to overturn. Once again, we did not. We accepted the procedures. We followed them. We took the advice on board. We made our decisions and we have given reasons for them. You cannot do much more than that. When you have got nothing else to run on, you try and keep going over the same old ground. This must be about the fourth occasion. If you really want long running records, why don't you get up and apologise to the Baillieus? Let us get back to something that really does have a few legs.

talk.start.para: âMy question goes to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is any Australian money directly or indirectly going via the World Bank to the proposed diversion of the Xiangride River in Tibet for an irrigation project? I also ask, regarding the arrest of Mr Gabriel Lafitte, Australian citizen, in that area eight days ago, why the Australian government is allowing itself to be treated as a doormat by the Beijing authorities over this matter. Why is it that it took two days for the Australian authorities to learn of this arrestâand then only through the US Embassy? Why was no legal aid or representation available throughout the six days detention of Mr Lafitte? What protest has gone to Beijing about the abrogation of basic rights to any Australian citizen in a foreign country when they are placed under arrest? Finally, what information has the government got about the fate of Mr Tsering Dorje, who was translating to that party? (Time expired)

âI do not know if there is any Australian money going via the World Bank into the river diversion referred to by Senator Brown, so I will seek information on that and provide an answer as soon as possible.

answer.para: In relation to Mr Lafitte, the situation is quite to the contrary of what Senator Brown said. My information is that consular officials did in fact act quicklyâfirstly to seek details from the ministry of foreign affairsâas soon as they became aware that he had been detained, and that it was certainly in part as a result of their active representations that he was ultimately released and, we are pleased, is now back in Australia. I am told that the embassy pursued the matter vigorously and was granted telephone contact with Mr Lafitte, who confirmed the contents of a previous letter that he had written to Australian officials. I can go into that if Senator Brown requires it, but it repeated that he was being treated well and did not require direct contact. It seems to the government that its officials acted properly in the best interests of an Australian in these circumstances, and, as I said, I am pleased that he has now been released.

In relation to those who were with him and who I understand are still detained, I do not know more than what is on the public record and I will see if the Australian government has been given any further information.

talk.start.para: âI ask the minister again: is it true that the Chinese authorities did not inform the Australian embassy about Mr Lafitte's detention but that came via the US Embassy? Secondly, can the minister inform the Senate as to why Mr Peter Nugent, Liberal member from Victoria in the House of Representatives, who was in the city of Xining where Mr Lafitte was under detention, packed his bags and left Xining, even though he was part of a human rights delegation, before making contact with this detained Australian?

âI repeat the facts as I know them, that is, the Australian consular officials became aware on 18 August that Mr Lafitte had been detained and that they made active representations. Firstly, they received a letter from him on 20 August, only two days later, in which he said he was happy with the way in which he was being treated and was confident a satisfactory outcome was imminent and that he did not require direct contact with the embassy. They then were able to make telephone contact with him. He then confirmed the contents of the letter, and repeated that he was being well treated and did not require direct contact. As I said, we are pleased that he has now been released.

subdebateinfo.title: Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Alston, Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. Does the minister recall that at the time he and his co-conspirator Senator Hill were only prepared to acknowledge 12â
âOrder! Senator Faulkner, there appears to be some imputation in that that I think ought not to be included in your question.
âIf there is an imputation, I withdraw it.
âI would ask you to withdraw that.
âIf there is, I withdraw it, Madam President.
âNo; I ask you to withdraw it.

âI do withdraw it. talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThis is just another backdoor entry exercise. What Senator Faulkner is trying to do is to identify the 16 projects. It is correct to say that, on the information provided to us, we originally advised the Senate estimates committees, separately, that there were 12 such projects. We subsequently corrected that, when it was brought to our attention that the accurate number was 16. I do not think anyone has seriously questioned the basis on which that occurred. What Senator Faulkner has been trying to do for monthsâin a fairly desultory fashion, I must say, until I suppose he got a bit of a kick along from someone in the gallery who was prepared to be misled by his assertionsâ
âName him.
âI have previously.
âHim or her.

âNo, him. What he is trying to do is simply to identify projects that he claims are shonky. If that is the view that he holds, then he is saying that 16 out of 60 projects are shonky. If that is the case, if Senator Faulkner is able to make that state mentâand he did not say that the process was; he said that the projects wereâwe have here an absolutely heaven-sent opportunity for Senator Faulkner to actually step up to the plate and tell us which of those 60 he regards as conceivably in the category of being shonky. âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. It is the minister who is accountable to this parliament. It is the minister who should step up to the plate and name the 16 projects. I would ask the minister to take the question on notice, as he is unwilling or unable to provide an answer now, and to give the Senate an answer later on today.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI do not think there was much of a question in that. But Senator Faulkner certainly knows the value of the 60 projectsâ$70 million, all of them good value. All you have got to doâ

âMadam President, on a point of order: there is a very clear question in there for Senator Alston, that is, if he does not know the value of the four extra projects, which he would not provide in answer to my original question, he should take it on notice and give it to the Senate later on today. That is the question: will he take it on notice and give that information to the Senate?
âThere is no point of order.

âSenator Faulkner clearly would like as much information as he can possibly get to misuse down the track. But if you are serious, if you have the opportunity to rethink that egregious mistake you made earlier and if you now realise in the cold, hard light of day that you should actually be concerned about outcomes and the quality of projects, then go away and have a look at all 60. I will give you at least 24 hours to do it. Go away and have a good look at them.
âName the 16.
âTalk to a few of your colleagues. See what you think of them. If you want any advice on them, we are more than happy to help you in that regard.
âName the 16.
âThen come back and tell us which ones you think are shonky.
âYou are the one that is accountable.
âOrder!
âIt is not his job to ask me questions. It is his job to answer.
âOrder, Senator Faulkner!

âMadam President, I raise a point of order: under standing order 203(b), (d) and (e), Senator Faulkner should be pulled into line in one way or another. In terms of standing order 203(b) he is `guilty of disorderly conduct'; in the terms of (d), he is persistently and wilfully refusing to conform to the standing orders; and in terms of (e) he is persistently and wilfully disregarding the authority of the Chair. He is now just starting to argue with you, Madam President. I urge you to take some action against Senator Faulkner for this unruly conduct that he continues to display in the Senate.

âI raise a point of order, Madam President. Question time is a forum where non-government senators ask ministers questions. It is ministers who are required to answer questions, not members of the opposition. Senator Alston has been asked a range of questions which you ought to direct him to answer. We have, specifically in relation to this point of order, a situation where Senator Alston is on the ropes; he has been protectedâ
âSenator Faulkner, you are debating the issueâ

âI am speaking to the point of order. We have spurious points of order being taken by, firstly, Senator Vanstone and, secondly, Senator Knowles, to waste time and to try to bat out a bit of time so Senator Alston cannot be asked questions by the opposition. We are going to keep going and we are going to keep asking questions, as we are entitled to. Madam President, I think you know it, and you ought to sit Senator Knowles down for such a spurious and outrageous breach of the standing orders and waste of the Senate's time.

âMadam President, on the point of order, I just ask you to consider that Senator Faulkner's behaviour in response to a legitimate point of order raised by Senator Knowles is evidence in itself of the point of order that she raises. Consistently, after you have called him to order, he immediately repeats the interjection you have called him to order for as a way of demonstrating to you that he is not going to take any notice. Then a few minutes later you have to call him to order again. I ask you, Madam President, to go back over the record and look at the occasions when you have called him to order and seconds later he has, in deliberate defiance of your order, proceeded with his unruly behaviour. âOn the point of order, Madam President, there is no point of order and you should swiftly rule both of the senators from the other side out of order, because all they are doing is trying to take the time of question time away from the opposition. So I will be brief. But in the consideration of doing that, Madam President, you should also be mindful that Senator Alston does not answer a single straight question and has not done so today; and that if this is the level of accountability from the government it is not surprising that the opposition will be very keen to pursue the government and make sure that it answers in this parliament to the Australian people on what is clearly a cover-up.

âThere has been considerable debate in these points of order. The minister must answer a question related to the subject matter of the question. He must be responsive to the question and he must respond in terms of his area of responsibility. I am not required to demand that he answer the question as the questioner wants it answered, but I am required to note these other factors. There have been considerable breaches of the standing orders this afternoon and I shall monitor carefully the behaviour of all senators.
âMy question is directed to Senator Macdonald, Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government.

question.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! That sort of behaviour of sledging and calling across the chamber is totally out of order.

âMadam President, the minister would be aware of today's announcement of Australian Bravery Decorations which again highlights the bravery and sacrifice of many Australians. As many of those mentioned are members of the fire, police and ambulance services, will the minister advise the Senate whether the government has any plans to recognise the contribution of Australia's permanent and volunteer emergency personnel in our national capital?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âI appreciate the question from Senator Watson, particularly in his role as the newly elected Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories. That question particularly relates to the national capital. I think all senators would agree with me that there would not be many Australians who have not been touched by the good work, the courage and compassion of the emergency services workers in Australia. It is accordingly with a great deal of pleasure that I announce that the government has decided to establish a National Emergency Services Memorial in Canberra.

answer.para: It is an Australian characteristic that we help each other out in times of danger of natural disaster and that the people at the forefront of that help are usually our professional and volunteer servicesâfirefighters, police men and women and ambulance officers. However, there has been no national place to commemorate their contribution and sometimes their sacrifice. The National Emergency Services Memorial will be on national land within the parliamentary triangle. The government is confident that the memorial will receive wide support from the Australian community as a fitting national focus for honouring the thousands of men and women who serve in our emergency services for the benefit of the wider community. The memorial will also provide a focus to commemorate those who have fallen or perished while carrying out their important duties to their fellow Australians.

I am particularly pleased that the Prime Minister has taken a personal interest in the provision of a permanent recognition of the work the emergency services workers do. As Senator Watson has said in his question, the matter is particularly in our minds today with the announcement of the bravery decorations, a number of which have gone to professional and volunteer emergency services personnel. As well, we have been thinking in recent times of the young policemen who were cut down in the course of their duty. Not too long ago, we were mourning the loss of firefighters caught by bushfires while trying to protect the lives and property of other Australians.

The government feels that it is fitting that a substantial memorial to honour their contribution is erected, and that that memorial recognise their contribution and the contribution made by other emergency services workers. I am pleased to advise the Senate that I have asked the National Capital Authority to conduct a design competition for the National Emergency Services Memorial. Leading Australian architects and sculptors will be asked to provide conceptual designs, as will members of the Australian community. I am sure that everyone in the Senate will agree that, as we approach the first 100 years of the Australian federation, it is fitting that a monument marking the enormous and valuable contribution of our emergency services workers be established in the centre of our national capital.

speech.para: Leave granted.

PITUITARY HORMONE INJECTIONS: COMPENSATION
SENATOR CROWLEY asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care, without notice, on 12 August 1999:

My question is to Senator Herron, representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Can the Minister advise when there will be a final outcome in the distribution of the $3 million promised to recipients of pituitary hormone injections which place them at risk of CJD? Wasn't this compensation promised by the government in March 1998 in response to the Senate committee inquiry into this major problem?
SENATOR HERRON âThe Minister for Health and Aged Care has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In its response to the Senate Community Affairs References Committee's Report on the CJD Settlement Offer the Government agreed to provide up to a further $3 million to the Pituitary Hormones Trust Account for payments to hormone recipients who have, or have suffered, a recognised psychiatric injury due to their having been informed they are at a greater risk of contracting CJD. It has also been agreed the six children of the four female hormone recipients who have died of CJD can apply for a one-off payment.

This funding is part of a $5.1 million package of measures to implement the Government's response to the Senate Committee's report which includes the establishment of an independent Advisory Board to assess applications for one-off payments for psychiatric illness, consideration of a longitudinal study of the health status of and further tracing of hormone recipients.

The Government has appointment Ms Robyn Layton QC as Chair of the independent Pituitary Hormones Trust Account Advisory Board which is currently considering claims for one-off payments for psychiatric illness, and determining which applicants are to receive a one-off payment and the amount of the payments. The Government has also appointed two psychiatrists, nominated by the Royal Australian & New Zealand College of Psychiatrists, as members of the Advisory Board.

A Special Edition of the Human Pituitary Hormones (HPH) newsletter was published in December 1998 to inform hormone recipients of the process for applying for a one-off payment. The original deadline for applications was February of this year but this was extended to May to ensure that all recipients of human pituitary derived hormones who wished to apply for a payment could do so. By the deadline of May the Department received approximately 300 applications.

The applicants have now all undergone a psychiatric assessment and the assessment reports are with the Advisory Board for its consideration. The Advisory Board aims to finalise its deliberations by the end of August and all applicants will receive advice of the outcome of their applications at that time.

SENATOR CROWLEY: Madam President, I have a supplementary question. Are you aware, Minister, that in April Minister Wooldridge stated that he believed the definition used for what constituted a psychiatric illness warranting compensation was broad and included psychiatric conditions described in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, known as DSM 4? Can the Minister now assure the Senate that this definition will ensure that the victims of the pituitary hormone experiments will be compensated if they have suffered severe depression, post traumatic trauma or stress related symptoms as a result of learning that their blood may carry the seed of a fatal illness which may strike them down many years in the future?

SENATOR HERRON: The Pituitary Hormones Trust Account Advisory Board regards the definition of psychiatric illness used in the Pituitary Hormones Trust Account Management and Administration Guidelines 1998 as including any psychiatric illness described in DSM-IV. For the purposes of the one-off payments psychiatric injury has been defined as "A recognised psychiatric illness that seriously impairs the mental functioning of a person, and is characterised by features which include but are not limited to; delusions, hallucinations, serious disorder of thought forms, severe disturbance of mood, sustained or repeated irrational behaviour." All assessing psychiatrists were contacted by the Department and advised that DSM-IV should be used when assessing a recipient. DSM-IV is one of the standard diagnostic reference works. DSM-IV does include conditions such as severe depression, post-traumatic trauma and stress.
The application of the definition is entirely a matter for the Board, which is an independent body.

As previously advised the independent Advisory Board is considering the applications it has received and will make a decision on which applicants are to receive a one-off ex-gratia payment and the amount of that payment.

PRE-EXISTING AILMENTS

Senator CROSSIN: My question is to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Is the Minister aware that, in April this year, the Minister for Health undertook to establish an inquiry into the pre-existing ailment rule, which has been misused by some health funds to deny benefits to people? What action has the Minister taken, and when will this inquiry be established?

Senator CROSSIN âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, can you confirm the report in the Courier-Mail on 4 August that the Minister for Health has received applications from health funds seeking a doubling of the waiting period for pre-existing conditions and ailments to no less than two years? Has the Minister made a decision on these applications and, if not, when will he refer them to the promised inquiry?
SENATOR HERRON âThe Minister for Health and Aged Care has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Following the Minister for Health and Aged Care's agreement to appoint three eminent people to conduct an inquiry that would review the operation of current pre-existing ailment rules for private health insurance, a letter was sent to several key organisations seeking nominations of candidates for appointment to the inquiry. Replies to this letter continued to arrive until early August. The Minister is now in the process of selecting candidates for appointment to the inquiry. Once this process is complete the inquiry can begin.

With regard to the Courier-Mail article of 4 August 1999, the Minister has considered and rejected the proposed extensions of the waiting periods for pre-existing ailments. This decision was based on the Department's advice that at the present time health funds are not able to provide sufficiently detailed data to justify waiting period extensions for specific procedures such as knee and hip reconstructions.

subdebateinfo.title: Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for the Environment and Heritage (Senator Hill) and the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts (Senator Alston), to questions without notice asked by Senators O'Brien, Cook and Faulkner today, relating to the distribution of funds for the Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects program.

I want to briefly clarify what is at issue here in the Senate today. The fact that the caretaker conventions require decisions to be made in advance of an election campaign is not at issue. Decisions in relation to the FCHP program were made in advance of the campaign. In fact, the government made damn sure they were. But did the PM sign off on the $70 million over breakfast on the Sunday morning before jumping in the limo to go to Government House or perhaps in the limo on the way there? Whatever the case, he certainly made sure that the $70 million was in the bag literally a few minutes before he went into the election campaign.
The most serious issue in relation to timing is the government's announcements in relation to the FCHP. The caretaker conventions state:
It is desirable, if the decisions concern significant initiatives, that they be announced in advance of the caretaker period in order to avoid controversy.

In announcing 32 of the 60 successful projects in the course of the campaign, the government blatantly ignored this injunction. The exercise of ministerial discretion in relation to the choice of successful grants is not at issue. We accept that, while ministers take advice from departments, they retain the final say. What is at issue is the refusal of Senators Hill and Alston to provide documented reasons for the exercise of discretion. Let us not forget that these are the very same people who cried foul when Ros Kelly refused to provide documented reasons for her exercise of ministerial discretion over the CCRSFP program. These are the people who pressed the Auditor-General to develop guidelines for discretionary grants programs. Those guidelines were ignored by Minister Hill and Minister Alston.

The assessment followed by the department is not at issue, and it is important that this be understood. That assessment process was clearly developed with regard to the Auditor-General's guidelines. What is at issue is that ministers chose to ignore the outcome of the process. One hundred and fourteen projects were ranked at 15 or more points out of 24. We want to knowâand under the Auditor-General's guidelines the ministers are obliged to tell usâwhy they chose 44 of these 114 as opposed to the other 70, why they chose to ignore nine of the 17 projects which were assessed at 19 points and above and why they chose 16 projects that did not even get to a ranking of 15 points. We argue that, where ministers choose to exercise their discretion, and particularly when this is done contrary to departmental advice, as in this case, their exercise of discretion must be justified and documented and it must be open to public scrutiny.

Finally, the worthiness of the projects is not an issue. It is not the projects which are shonky, or at least we have no basis at this stage on which to conclude otherwise. It is the process in the ministerial office without any departmental officers present by which the 60 successful projects were chosen that is the shonk. Until the ministers concernedâthat is, Senator Hill and Senator Alstonâcan produce reasons to back up their decisions and produce a paper trail to back up their decisions and address the real issues, rather than respond to non-issues or not respond at all, as we saw with Senator Alston in the chamber today, we are going to go on calling it a shonk.

We want accountability. We want the reasons for this Federation Fund fiddle. We want the identity of the 16 projects about which the ministers believed they knew more than the departments. We want to know what projects they pulled out of their bottom drawers. We are going to go on demanding answers until we get them.

talk.start.para: âThe Leader of the Opposition in the Senate can say what he likes about the Federation Fund. The fund has worked remarkably well. It is such a great achievement by the coalition government to think it could implement a fund of that nature that had such a wide positive effect across Australia that I would have thought there would be applause from the other side. But evidently the other side is as hollow on this issue as it is on many other issues. The Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects program, otherwise known by the acronym FCHP, is absolutely administered in a most impeccable way. Senator Faulkner on the other side is saying, `We don't really know what's going on, but you tell us.' That is like saying that you are guilty until you are proven innocent.

âThank you. I appreciate Senator Conroy interjecting. The Auditor-General did find that there was something radically wrong with the whiteboard system of the distribution of money, and the minister paid the price. I have to say that I am concerned when a socialist partyâthe major opposition party on the other sideâ
âPardon?
âthe socialist partyâdoes not supportâ
âRoss!

âSenator Conroy, yours is hardly a conservative party.

âHe is absolutely incorrigible, Madam Deputy President. I really thought that this was one of those rare occasions when we could have bipartisan support. Instead of that, you are bellyaching, carping and fishingâ

âI am addressing the chair, Madam Deputy President; I do not know what else I can do.
âI think you had better read what you have said.

Senator Conroy interjectingâ

âIt's the other way around.
âIn any case, what happened has been fully explained and I am not going to go through the questions.

speech.para: Senator Carr interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senator Carr!

âMy colleague spoke about departmental figures. You cannot not blame anyone, but that does not make the issue any less valid than it is. You bring these issues up, you know they are spurious, you envy what we do and you try and take it down because you know that the people of Australia embrace totally what this government is doing with respect to conservation. The Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects are commendable from any angle and the opposition should embrace those initiatives fully.

âI also rise to take note of the questions and answers given today on this issue. I would like to thank Senator Lightfoot for that entertaining but irrelevant defence of his government's position. What the government, including Senators Hill and Alston, have not told Senator Lightfoot is about the departmental submission to the ministers involved.
âIs it a submission?
âI am about to read from an FOI document, so it is perfectly available to youâthrough you, Madam Deputy Presidentâas well. It is available; it is on the public record. It starts off by stating:

speech.para: Purpose:
To provide you with a list of highly rated cultural/heritage and heritage projects from which to select for funding under the FCHP.
It goes on to say:

that is, the ministersâ
on 9 July 1998, the department's assessment process is now complete.

talk.start.para: âThat is the `12' and the `16', Senator Lightfoot. That is where the mistake was. Your ministers misled the parliament to start with, and then, during the election campaign, they leaked out all the successful projects. Did they tell the communities whose projects failed? During the election campaign, did they write and say, `We're sorry. You didn't get a grant'? They rushed to get the yeses out, but what about the noes? Nothing. Six weeks later the noes were told. Why did the nine projects that were rated by the government's departmental advice as `very high' fail? Why did the 16 projects which fell below the 15-point departmental target get up? They will not tell us. This is what the department referred to when they talked about the projects below 15 points. They said:

speech.para: . . . [they] did not compare well in terms of significance or community benefit to the highest ranked projects, or, answer concerns about the ability of the organisation to deliver the project on time and within budget and/or had ongoing viability problems.

That is what the department said. The ones below 15 fall into that sort of category. That was from the department, Senator Lightfoot, not the Labor Party. This government has pulled out the marginal seats lists. Come clean! You were sitting there days before the election, and you wanted to do a bit of simple old-fashioned pork-barrelling. You went through the marginal Liberal seatsâwhere you were under a bit of pressure from One Nationâand you slipped a few of them in.

All we are saying is, if it is all aboveboard as you claim, put it on the record. Look at the FOI requests. What do you get under `lists of reasons'? The lists of reasons are blanked out. The lists of reasons for why the projectsâall 60 of themâwere approved have been blanked out. There is nothing in the FOI documents; they have not provided information. The question is why. The answer is obvious. This is blatant pork-barrelling and hypocrisy in extraordinary proportions from Senators Alston and Hill. Senators Alston and Hill are guilty of the most outrageous hypocrisy and should resign.

talk.start.para: âWhat we are seeing this afternoon is a trawling exercise carried out by a desperate opposition with no policies and no programs. They are trying to besmirch the names of two of the most successful ministers in the parliament. The poor old ALP over there have not got anything going for them, and so they have to sink down to these sorts of gutter tacticsâtrawling around looking for a bit of mud to throw. Senator Conroy is hanging his head in shame and leaving the chamber because he knows it is true.

speech.para: The process which was gone through to fund the Federation and Cultural Heritage Projects Program was very open and transparent. Applications were called for on 30 June 1998. The task group's assessment began on 13 July and was completed on 13 August. The National Council for the Centenary of Federation provided its advice to the ministers on 7 August. The Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts sent a minute to the ministers on 14 August, along with copies of all applications and the task group's evaluations. The ministers forwarded a list of their recommended projects to the Prime Minister on 27 August. A letter dated 30 August was sent to the ministers, advising them of the PM's approval. That is all pretty straightforward.

Let us look at the criteria and process. There were 741 applications. The projects were evaluated by a task group made up of officers of DOCITA and the Department of the Environment and Heritage. The projects were judged against six criteria: significance, lasting nature, appropriateness for the Centenary of Federation, benefits to the broad community, good management capability, and partnerships in funding. The projects were scored. They were given four points for each of those six criteria, leading to a possible score of 24. Far from 16 projects not meeting the minimum criteria, in fact 60 projects were successful and eligible to be considered. The story which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on 11 August, under the by-line of Mike Seccombe, was very wrong and very misleading. Whoever leaked the information to him should have checked it out first, because it was wrong.

In making their final decisions, as well as taking into account the evaluations of the task group and the national council, the ministers took into account the need to fund a balance of cultural and heritage projects, a balance of projects in each state and territory, and a balance of projects in inner metropolitan, outer metropolitan and regional areas. Ministers were not provided with a list of recommended projects; rather, they were provided with all the information so they could select worthwhile projects, taking these objectives into account. That is what they did. It is true that some of the projects were announced during the election campaign, but that is not a breach of the caretaker conventions.

talk.start.para: âOf course it is!

âOf course it is not. That is absolute nonsense, Senator Carr. You know it is not in breach. You are desperately picking up a little bit of mud and flinging it, but it is not going to stick because it is not a breach of the caretaker conventions which state that significant decisions should not be made during a campaign. These decisions were made before the caretaker period came into effect and were merely announced during the caretaker period.

speech.para: What we have here is a trawling exercise by an opposition which, when in government, did almost nothing for the environment and nothing for natural heritageâit failed to reverse land and water degradation, it failed to do anything about the decline in biodiversity and it failed to prevent the spread of weeds and of feral animals such as foxes, goats, cats and cane toads. It basically neglected both the environment and natural heritage.

The money from the Building Better Cities program went to the cities because that is where the problems were. The money from the environmental programs has gone to the country areas and country electorates because that is where the problems are. I hope and pray that during the rest of this session the opposition will do a little bit better than it has done on this issue, trawling around, trying to make an issue out of nothing. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âWhile the government refuses to explain why and how it came to hand-pick 16 projects out of the Federation Fund moneys and why it did so in breach of the clear criteria that it had established and agreed to with the department, the opposition will maintain its charges that this program was rorted. We are quite clearly seeing an attempt by this government to hide from public scrutiny a shameless use of public funds for quite clear electoral purposes. An attempt is being made by this government to hide the fact that 16 projects were hand-picked by government ministers in such a way as to allow for the maximum political impact in support of coalition marginal seats during the last election.

speech.para: This is a policy which this government has pursued quite clearly in total disregard for the long-held convention `that significant initiatives should be announced in advance of the caretaker period in order to avoid controversy'. That is the sentiment that is expressly stated in the caretaker conventions which have long been established within this parliament. This is quite clearly a breach by this government. The government has attempted to hide its contempt for the Auditor-General's guidelines.

I further allege that this government has sought to circumvent an FOI request which would have allowed the parliament to get to the bottom of what is quite clearly a shonky grants process. What we have before us is the motivation of the government. Senators are entitled to ask questions about that. It is my contention that this government was under considerable pressure in the last election. It was quite prepared to use public resources at its disposal to pork-barrel its way out of trouble.

In particular, we note that one of the ministers concerned with the administration of this program, Senator Alston, happened to be the campaign director for the Liberal Party in the state of Victoria. It was not above his consideration to have press conferences at the Liberal Party campaign headquarters at Nauru House in Melbourne. For instance, on 8 September 1998 he stated quite explicitly that the Liberal Party was in a very tight election and that all stops had to be pulled out to make sure that people understood the stark choices, and so on, before them. The stark choices to which he referred included the use of funds under the Federation Fund program. The transcript of that interview is publicly available.

We have to understand the simple facts behind this matter. Mr Fischer blew the gaff on this government when he confirmed on ABC TV during its election night coverage that a lot of policy was in the pipeline and that specific projects are always held back for announcement during an election campaign. The simple facts are that, in the months leading up to the calling of the election on 30 August last year, government ministers approved $198 million in grants under the Natural Heritage Trust, $170 million in Federation Fund major project grants, and $70 million in Federation Fund Cultural and Heritage Projectsâa total of $438 million. In the course of the election campaign itself, the government announced $198 million in grants under the Natural Heritage Trust, $317 million in Federation Fund major projects and $41 million in terms of the Federation Fund Cultural and Heritage Projects.

It is quite apparent that there has been considerable political interference in the allocation of government moneys to the Federation Fund projects. It is quite apparent to us that secrecy surrounding why the decisions were made and the failure of the government to release publicly the documentation which it alleged it sent to the department indicates that the government has a considerable amount to hide in this regard. I ask the simple question: why should such secrecy surround the expenditure of such significant sums of money?

Some 16âor more than 25 per centâof the 60 successful projects in the cultural fund were chosen by ministers who were obviously content to override departmental advice and to contravene the Auditor-General's guidelines in pursuit of votes. Quite clearly, that is the criterion that was primarily in their minds when it came to the allocation of moneys for this project. The department presented a list of 114 projects and 16 of these projects were below the cut-off line. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âWe are taking note of answers to questions that were raised in the Senate this afternoon. I would like to preface my remarks by saying that many of the questions and the matters that arose during question time actually challenged the authority of the chair. I think it is unfortunate when the position of the chair is not respected. That is a matter that all sides of this parliament should acknowledge.

speech.para: There were great inconsistencies between the presentation that we have just heard from Senator Carr and the earlier contribution by his leader, Senator Faulkner. They were completely divergent approaches to the same issue. In fact, Senator Carr, if you read the transcript of what Senator Faulkner said, you will see that he did not actually take issue with the question of the announcement during the election campaign; whereas, you did and you put a lot of store on that. Where is the consistency in your approach to answering this question and the approach of Senator Faulkner, who took a completely different tack? He was concerned about certain aspects of the process, but he actually said that the announcement during the election campaign was not the issue. On the other hand, Senator Carr, you attempted to make it the issue, and I think you erred in that respect.

If I may follow the issue raised by Senator Eggleston, some projects were of course announced in the campaign. That was not in breach of the caretaker conventions which state that significant decisions should not be madeâwith the emphasis on `made'âduring a campaign. The point that I wish to emphasise is that the decisions were actually made before the caretaker period came into effect and were merely announced during the caretaker period. There is the big inconsistency, I submit, between what your leader articulated to the Senate and what you took offence to, Senator Carr. I think on this occasion, on this particular issue, I must defer to the side of your esteemed leader.

The Labor Party has attempted to make an issue of this by claiming that decisions were taken in response to vulnerable seats and vulnerable areas, et cetera. Senator Mackay and other Tasmanian senators are in the chamber at present. I would just like to mention that Tasmania has actually benefited from six of these particular projects. The Launceston Railway Workshop Museum was a concept that was originally started by, I think, Lance Barnard many years ago. It would certainly have been a retrograde step had we not built on that development at the Inveresk railway yards. True, we built on that. The foundation was good, and I think it is going to be a centre of great cultural and heritage significance well into the future. If we had not spent moneyâa modest sumâin that area, I think you would have attacked us for not looking after proper heritage issues.

Another project in your home town, Senator Mackay, is the historic Female Factory in Hobart. This $0.975 million project certainly was not in a Liberal held seat at the time and nor is it nowâagain completely refuting all of your arguments. Then we move to the electorate of Lyons in respect of which Dick Adams was the incumbent at the time. An amount of $0.7 million was spent in the central midlands. Then there is the Devonport cultural heritage project. As we know, parts of Devonport are in Lyons and parts of it are in Braddon. Again, I do not know that you could say that there was any particular advantage in that area.

The Clarendon Homestead project is in Dick Adams's electorate of Lyonsâhardly a bias towards the Liberal Party. So this is a whole lot of bunkum that you are going on with, particularly in the state of Tasmania where we also have the school of fine furniture. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of Senator Cooney, I present report No. 23 of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties entitled Amendments proposed to the International Whaling Convention , together with submissions, Hansard record of proceedings and minutes.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: âI seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The statement read as followsâ

The report I have just tabled is the fourth examination of amendments proposed to the Schedule to the International Convention for the Regulation of Whaling, 1946 , by the Treaties Committee since it was established in 1996.

Each year since 1949, the International Whaling Commission (IWC) has met to review the Schedule which has been amended to reflect the considerable changes, in technology and other areas, that have occurred since the Convention was signed in 1946.
The two sets of proposed amendments to the Schedule arose from the 51st Annual Meeting of the IWC, held in Grenada in May 1999.

The first set proposed to alter dates in the Schedule to this Convention to renew the moratorium on commercial whaling, introduced in 1986. As on the three past occasions, these proposed changes were supported by the Committee.
The other set of proposed amendments was more controversial. It dealt with the renewal of a quota for aboriginal subsistence whaling.
In spite of the moratorium on commercial whaling, in certain circumstances the IWC allows the taking of whales, notably under its aboriginal subsistence whaling provisions.

There are records of this whaling occurring as early as 1500BC. It has been recognised by international treaties for 60 years as being in some way different to, and having a distinctive character and thus susceptible to other controls for, commercial whaling.

Since the early 1970s, the IWC has strengthened its conservation policy by putting new management procedures in place. Agreed definitions, management principles and guidelines were adopted in the early 1980s for this category of whaling, and broad management objectives were also adopted.

While there is a range of definitions in the Convention and in the Schedule, it is not complete. The agreed definitions of `aboriginal subsistence whaling', `local aboriginal consumption', `subsistence catches and `subsistence use of whale products' do not form part of either document. Nor are terms such as `aboriginal, `culture' or `subsistence' defined. Finally, there are no formal, defined links between aboriginal subsistence whaling and traditional methods of killing.

This is a difficult area that demands a sensitive approach. The Alaskan Eskimos clearly fall within the IWC's guidelines and have one of the five quotas currently allowed for aboriginal subsistence whaling. Without allocating quotas to particular groups of aboriginal people, paragraph 13(b) of the Schedule allocates yearly catch limits from particular stocks of whales.

Since 1987, the Bequian people of St Vincent and The Grenadines have been allocated a quota of three and then two humpback whales, provided that the meat and products of such whales are used exclusively for local consumption. The Schedule forbids taking or killing suckling calves or female whales accompanied by calves.

We do not believe that the quota for the Bequian people has ever been sufficiently justified. Demonstration of cultural and nutritional needs is at the heart of aboriginal subsistence whaling. The Bequians have produced what was essentially a history of whaling in their area as a justification for their quota. They do not have the history of whaling for cultural and tradition reasons other peoples can and have provided.

For some time, evidently, there was support for this quota because all their whaling was done by one old man and it was said the practice would die out with him. It now appears that he has been succeeded by his nephew.

The Bequians have not been able to provide the sort of detailed needs statement of their need that should be required for the allocation of an aboriginal subsistence whaling quota. We see this as a deficiency in the IWC's approach: other peoples with a history of whaling could use the Bequian precedent to seek status as aboriginal subsistence whalers. In such a way could the moratorium on commercial whaling be weakened.

Although decisions within the IWC are reached by consensus, there seem to be several voting groups within the IWC. Australia is seen by some observers as one of the more conservation-minded nations. Other nations, such as Japan and Norway, are seen by some other members to use the Convention's provisions to take whales.

Japan uses the provisions of Article VIII of the Convention to issue special permits for `scientific' whaling. Norway submitted an objection to the moratorium under Article V and has continued commercial whaling. Some nations see these provision as loopholes in the Convention that could be used as means to allow full scale resumption of commercial whaling.

The 52nd Annual Meeting of the IWC will be held in Adelaide in June-July 2000. The Committee believes that this is an opportunity to revise the Convention and its Schedule. We believe that there are real difficulties in the continued smooth operation of these documents. We see the meeting in 2000 as an opportunity to begin revising the Convention and its Schedule. Accordingly, we have recommended that the Australian Government should:
. prepare a proposal for consideration at that meeting to revise the provisions of the Convention and its Schedule;
. lodge an expression of concern about the renewal of the quota for the Bequian people, and indicate that this matter will be raised at the meeting in 2000;
. request the IWC to obtain a detailed needs statement from the Bequian people for consideration at that meeting, but
. should not lodge a formal objection to the renewal of the quota proposed by the second set of amendments.

It would have been easy to have recommended lodging an objection to the renewal of this quota. We believe that an expression of concern, together with the other recommendations we have made, will be more effective.

Finally, we acknowledge that not all Parties within the IWC will welcome our proposal to revise the Convention and its Schedule. If it is accepted and does proceed, at some point it may be necessary to judge how far and how fast it should be pushed.

Pro-whaling nations within the IWC are unlikely to permit the closure of what are seen as loopholes in the Convention. In any event, it would be foolish to allow a desire for reform to push some countries outside the IWC and its processes.
I commend the Report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.para: That these bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The speeches read as followsâ
THE SUPERANNUATION (UNCLAIMED MONEY AND LOST MEMBERS) BILL 1999

The Superannuation (Unclaimed Money and Lost Members) Bill 1999 (the bill) establishes a scheme for ensuring that superannuation members who have lost contact with their fund have a comprehensive register to check where their superannuation is held. The bill will overcome deficiencies in existing provisions relating to unclaimed money and lost members.

With the increased superannuation coverage brought about by the superannuation guarantee arrangements introduced in 1992, many casual and itinerant workers (eg. farm and mining labourers) and those with broken employment patterns became `lost' members in that they lost the paperwork associated with their account, were never given the paperwork because they terminated employment before their superannuation guarantee contributions were made or lost contact with their fund in other circumstances.
The bill will particularly benefit employees who have changed jobs regularly, who have moved interstate or overseas and who have multiple superannuation accounts.

The bill formalises the Commissioner of Taxation's administration of unclaimed superannuation money and the details of lost members. This recognises the experience and efficiencies that the Australian Taxation Office has in system administration.
The bill also has a number of other important objectives. The bill:
. provides for greater co-operation between the Commonwealth, States and Territories in reuniting members with their superannuation;

. extends the use of the tax file numbers (TFNs) to lost members and unclaimed superannuation money held by the States and Territories consistent with the use of TFNs in other parts of the superannuation industry (eg. superannuation funds and unclaimed superannuation money held by the Commonwealth); and
. ensures consistent taxation treatment of unclaimed superannuation money held by the States and Territories.

The bill will result in a small unquantifiable increase in revenue due to the application of consistent taxation treatment to unclaimed superannuation money held by the States and Territories. The bill will also lead to a substantial reduction in administration costs for the Commonwealth, States and Territories as a consequence of provisions facilitating greater co-operation between stakeholders and by extending the use of TFNs to lost members and unclaimed superannuation money held by the States and Territories.
The bill has a minimal compliance cost impact.
Full details of the measures in this bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum.
I commend the bill.
SUPERANNUATION (UNCLAIMED MONEY AND LOST MEMBERS) CONSEQUENTIAL AND TRANSITIONAL BILL 1999

The Superannuation (Unclaimed Money and Lost Members) Consequential and Transitional Bill 1999 makes consequential and transitional amendments to Commonwealth legislation as a result of the Superannuation (Unclaimed Money and Lost Members) Bill 1999.
Full details of the measures in this Bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum.
I commend the bill.
MINISTERS OF STATE AMENDMENT BILL 1999

The Ministers of State Act 1952 prescribes the maximum annual sum for the payment of salaries to Ministers. Amendments to this act are therefore required from time to time to cover changes in the level of ministerial salaries or the number of Ministers.

The sum was increased to 1.64 million dollars for the 1995-96 financial year to meet increases in salaries for Ministers under the previous Government, and was reduced by this Government to 1.6 million dollars for future years. At the time it was noted that, had the previous Government remained in office, it would have been necessary to increase the annual sum appropriated to 1.78 million dollars.

The size of the Ministry has been increased from 28 to 30 since 1996, but the salaries of Ministers not in Cabinet have remained significantly lower than the salaries of Cabinet Ministers. The present modest increase in the annual sum has been necessitated by the increase in the number of Cabinet Ministers from 16 to 17 in October 1998.
AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1999

The bill amends the Australian Tourist Commission Act 1987 by removing the requirement that the Commission ensure an outcome in relation to environmental and social impacts over which it has no power. This requirement is replaced with one that will ensure that the Commission maintains its involvement in social and environmental issues, but at a level appropriate to its powers in these areas.

The principal objectives of the Australian Tourist Commission are set out in Section 6 of the act. They are (a) to increase the number of visitors to Australia from overseas; (b) to maximise the benefits to Australia from overseas visitors; and (c) to ensure that Australia is protected from adverse environmental and social impacts of international tourism.

The Australian Tourist Commission works effectively as an international marketer of Australian tourism to meet its first two objects. The Commission does not have the power or capability to meet its third object, as has been pointed out by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit and the Australian National Audit Office, to ensure that Australia is protected from adverse environmental and social impacts of international tourism. While the Commission undertakes a number of activities aimed at protecting the environment and society from adverse impacts of international tourism, these measures could not be considered sufficient to "ensure" protection.
This has presented the Commission with a number of reporting and accountability problems.

The Australian National Audit Office indicated in its 1997/98 Review "Aspects of Corporate Governance; The Australian Tourist Commission" that the Commission was unable to demonstrate that it was fully meeting all of its statutory objects, particularly the object relating to ensuring the protection of Australia from adverse environmental and social impacts. Additionally, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, in its Review of Auditor-General's Reports 1997-98, has recommended that the Commission should propose to its Minister that this statutory object should be amended to clarify the Commission's role.
The proposed amendment will allow the Commission to meet its statutory objects without removing its social and environmental responsibilities.
There will be no additional expenditure by the Commonwealth as a result of this bill.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator O'Brien) adjourned.
Ordered that the Ministers of State Amendment Bill 1999 and the Australian Sports Commission Amendment Bill 1999 be listed on the Notice Paper as separate orders of the day.
