talk.start.para: âThey don't pay it.

speech.para: As I said, we have had discussions with local councils, and we hold ourselves ready to have discussions with local councils. âI asked a series of questions earlier and I did not obtain an answer to them. To go back, we carried the GST legislation about two or three months ago. Now we have a A New Tax System (Commonwealth-State Financial Arrangements) Bill 1999 to amend it. My first question is: does anything in this bill require the publicity campaign, costing Australian taxpayers $10 million, to be altered? speech.para: A fourth question has arisen from the examination of you by my colleagues interested in local government: Minister, what educative publicity, under the heading of this campaign, is provided to local government to answer the obvious queries that they have? talk.start.para: âSenator Cook, I keep asking people to address the chair. Every time you use the word `you', it refers to me.

âYou are quite right, Madam Chairman. I stand rebuked and I apologise to you for that. Madam Chairman, Senator Kemp earlier started to warm to his subject and talked about the so-called advantages of a GST on exports. He never quite developed his argument, but let me kill this furphy before it gets any further. Exports are zero rated. The government aggregates the so-called taxes that would be saved to Australian exporters and argues that this is somehow a windfall gain to Australian exporters. The government has not told usâunder probing by the Senate committee we extracted this from the Department of the Treasuryâthat the impact of those changes will force up the exchange rate by between three and four points. Therefore, those exporters who are in markets that are overhung by supplyâwhere they are price takers, not price setters; that is, classically, the entire minerals market as well as the entire agricultural export marketâwill be worse off because they will have higher prices, and they will not have the competitive advantage delivered to them as well.

speech.para: I note that the adviser is leaning over to advise the minister on the arguments he should use about this. But I remind the minister that the evidence of the Treasury said that this is the knock-on effect. As a consequence, while there will be savings, the knock-on effect will mean that there will be higher costs; in the case of our most vulnerable exporters, costs that will make them less, not more, competitive. With those remarks, I return to my questions and I look forward to an answer.

talk.start.para: âOn the last question, which was on the effects on exports, the fact of the matter is that the exporters prefer our tax model to yours. As you said, exports are zero rated and, frankly, I do not think there would be an exporter in this country who would want to go back to the Labor Party tax model.
âWant to bet?

âWe had a bet, in a sense, in the last election. You lost that. We had a major debate in this chamber over a very long period. You lost that. The government is carrying out its proper responsibilities and informing the public. I am not aware of any change which may be required as a result of any material going through here. You have raised the question and so I will look at that issue, but I am not aware as I stand here of any changes.

You asked why the GST is not mentioned in the campaign. The GST is the centrepiece of the campaign. If you go into the Internet or phone the infolines, you will find that the word `GST' appears constantly, I would have thought. We are encouraging people to seek information on the GST. I am not sure what you are driving at but it seems to me that there is a great deal of information out there on the GST. I think that covers the matters that Senator Cook raised. There are some issues on which Senator Cook and I will undoubtedly differ in matters of public debate but, as I said, I will always try to assist him with answers to questions.

talk.start.para: âIn an endeavour to enable the minister to do the same again, let me ask another question. Senator Kemp says he is not the one who authorises the advertisements. Who does? Which minister takes responsibility? Secondly, there is no mention of the GST in the television advertising. Why is there no mention of the GST in the television advertising?

âI understand that the committee that approves this is a very distinguished committeeânot that this has anything to do with the bill, I might say. It has nothing to do with the bill, so I think we should attempt to confine ourselves to the legislation before the chamber. We have had very long debates on the goods and services tax and no-one has ever resiled from using that term as far as I am aware. The relevant committee is chaired by a very distinguished senator on our sideâSenator Ellisonâwho, as in everything he touches, does a very good job. I have no reason to query his particular work in this regard. I frankly think that to suggest that people are hiding the word `GST' is absurd. We had an election on the GST. The Labor Party said it was a referendum on the GST.
âAnd you lostâ48 per cent of the vote was all the government got. As a referendum on the GST, you lost.

âIf we lost and you won, I am very happy with the result because we seem to be over here and you seem to be over there. I hope you have many more victories like this, Senator Conroy, if that is the case. I do not know what point Senator Cook was making about not mentioning the GST. Those three letters must have sunk into the public consciousness by now. No-one is hiding anything. We are trying to inform people. They will get a host of material where the term `goods and services tax' is mentioned. We are proud of the system that we have brought in. We are not trying to hide anything from the public. This has been the most relentlessly exposed election promise and these have been the most relentlessly debated bills before this parliament, and so no-one is trying to hide anything.

âI have had a brief opportunity to address the documents and it appears that the return to order is not complied with. I seek leave to make a statement in relation to the matter.

talk.start.para: âThe minister in this place, Senator Macdonald, said:

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of Senator Mackay, I move:

speech.para: That the amendment of section 95.55 of the Civil Aviation Orders, dated 30 April 1999, and made under regulation 308 of the Civil Aviation Regulations 1988, be disallowed.

The opposition has moved to disallow these particular changes for a very simple reasonâthat is, the failure of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority to consult with those most affected by these changes. What we have here, unfortunately, once again, is a failure of the process on CASA's partâa failure yet again to sit down and go through proposed changes to the aviation regulatory framework with the pilots, aircraft owners and manufacturers most affected by them.

This situation, I might say, is a reminder to the Senate of what one would have thought would have been a very salutary lesson that CASA might have learned from the very public class G airspace debacle of several months ago where, I think it is fair to say, a large component of the failure of that particular exercise was due to CASA's unwillingness to properly consult with, and to listen to, airspace users. The changes that are the subject of this disallowance are of a much lesser order in that they affect a much smaller number of people, but they are significant to the ultralight aviation industry affected by them and they do reflect a continuation of that pattern of inadequate consultation and poor process that we unfortunately saw surrounding the class G airspace trial.

The background to this disallowance began in May last year when CASA published a notice of proposed rule making entitled, `Increase in ultralight aeroplane maximum take-off weight limit'. A notice of proposed rule making is basically the first public step in the process of changing aviation regulations. It is a notice that lets aviation communities know what changes CASA is proposing, and it provides an opportunity for comment on the changes. This particular notice stated that CASA intended to increase to 544 kilograms the maximum take-off weight of aeroplanes certified under Civil Aviation Order 101.55. These are ultralight, amateur builtâthat is, home builtâaircraft.

In this case CASA received a number of comments on the notice of proposed rule making and decided to amend Civil Aviation Order 95.55 instead of Civil Aviation Order 101.55. It seems to me that, irrespective of subsequent events, CASA should have issued a new notice of proposed rule making before proceeding to amend CAO 95.55. That would have been the proper process. But CASA apparently decided it was unnecessary to publish any notice on its changes to Civil Aviation Order 95.55 and proceeded to amend that civil aviation order in 1998. The problem was that new items were incorporated into the Civil Aviation Order 95.55 amendmentsâthat is, items that had not appeared in the original notice of proposed rule making appeared but they had not been the subject of any consultation with the ultralight community. In effect, these new changes removed the approval for ultralight aircraft to enter controlled airspace.

It seems to me that the push for these changes to the regulatory regime was driven by a small section of the aviation industry that remains opposed to amateur built aircraft owners being able to register and operate their aircraft within the Australian Ultralight Federation. I put on record here that the opposition has no problem with such an arrangement and considers the Australian Ultralight Federation to be a diligent organisation that takes its safety responsibilities seriously.

Ultralight pilots were alarmed and angry that these changes had occurred without consultation with them. They were of the viewâand I am advised they remain of the viewâthat access to controlled airspace is essential in some areas, and in some circumstances essential for safety reasons. CASA subsequently accepted that it had failed to follow proper consultation processes and re-amended Civil Aviation Order 95.55 to remove the items concerned. The re-amended order was gazetted on 30 April 1999.
In an email to the Australian Ultralight Federation, the Director of CASA, Mick Toller, stated that this action:
. . . returns the position to what legally prevailed before the weight increase changes took effect.

Now CASA says it is putting new consultation processes in place to prevent such a situation occurring in future and is also preparing a discussion paper addressing the issue of allowing ultralight aircraft to enter and fly through controlled airspace. But the problem is that CASA has not returned the position to what legally prevailed prior to the initial amendment to Civil Aviation Order 95.55. In particular, a new definition of stall speed has been included and remains in the amended order.

In the old Civil Aviation Order 95.55, the aircraft had to have a stall speed that did not exceed 45 knots indicated air speed. In the amended Civil Aviation Order 95.55, the aircraft stall speed must not exceed 45 knots CASâthat is, calibrated air speed. There seems to have been no mention of calibrated air speed prior to the gazettal of the re-amended Civil Aviation Order 95.55 on 19 May, and there has been no consultation, I am advised, with the relevant sections of the industry at this point.

All of this is a pretty technical argument because we are dealing with technical matters here. Without going too deeply into the technical aspects of this matter, indicated airspeed is essentially, I am advised, the reading taken from an aircraft's airspeed indicator. It is a reading used by pilots to adjust their aircraft's performance. Take off, climb, approach, landing and stall speeds are based on indicated air speed. It is considered a sufficiently accurate measurement for light aircraft flying at relatively low altitudes and relatively low speeds.

Calibrated airspeed, on the other hand, is an accurate and technical indication of airspeed. Measuring calibrated airspeed requires extensive in-flight testing with significant additional technical equipment on board. I am advised that most pilots of light aircraft do not concern themselves with calibrated airspeed. However, where there is a manufacturer involved, handbooks issued by those aircraft manufacturers list the calibrated airspeed for various elements of an aircraft's performance, and pilots can refer to these if required. In this case, we are talking about aircraft which are essentially non-commercially homemade. One can envisage a great many circumstances where an owner would have no such manufacturer's technical specification to rely upon. It may be that CASA has decided to require a measurement of calibrated airspeed right across the boardâfor all classes of aircraft. It is not clear just how much safer that would make ultralight or microlight aviation, but it might be considered a legitimate and consistent approach to take.

However, in this case the problem is that CASA have not actually told anyone that that is what they are planning to do. They have not consulted anyone on that point. The Australian Ultralight Federation argue that the inclusion of calibrated airspeed will impose additional costs on Australian amateur built ultralights with no improvement in safety. They also argue that it discriminates against the category of amateur built aircraft, as other categories do not include such a requirement. But the Australian Ultralight Federation's biggest concern is that the change was incorporated with no consultation whatsoever with the relevant sections of the industry, most notably ultralight pilots and Australian ultralight manufacturers. The Australian Ultralight Federation informed me that they believe the issue to be so significant that CASAâif they wanted to introduce this new requirement either in a specific category or across the boardâshould go through the appropriate and established process; that is, issue a notice of proposed rule making and undertake proper consultation following that.

The opposition is of a like view. Should we be successful in moving for this disallowance, we would urge that CASA go back to the start of this process, do it properly with the proper consultation and, in consulting those industries most affected by the measures, explain exactly what they are doing and why and give them a proper opportunity to have an input into the process. At the end of the day, I suspect that the opposition which underlies this might be satisfied if the matter is proceeded with. Given what I said earlier about the failings of CASA with regard to consultation and the lesson one would argue they should have learnt from the absolute debacle of the public class G trial failure, one would think CASA would have been very careful to ensure that any process they followed involved full and open consultation with the sections of industry affected. Had that been the case, I suspect there might have been a different response from organisations such as the Ultralight Federation. But, of course, we do not and will not know that because the process in this case has not been followed. The aviation community, or the sections of the community affected by this change, believe that they have been ambushed by the change in regulation. They do not accept that it is necessary. They do not believe they have had an opportunity to argue their case. They believeâas does the oppositionâthat this regulation ought to be disallowed and that, if CASA intend to proceed, they begin the process again and conclude it following the appropriate procedures.

talk.start.para: âI refer to Senator O'Brien's earlier comments about the return to order that has just been tabled. The Deputy Prime Minister's office has advised me that the Skehill report should be completed at the end of the month and that the report will be tabled once it is completed. speech.para: Let me stress at the outset that the government's mandate to CASA is to rewrite the aviation safety regulatory framework so that it is globally harmonised. The government's aim is to create one tier of delegated legislationâthe civil aviation safety regulations. Australian standards will be neither more lenient nor more onerous than those in major aviation nations such as the US, the UK and Canada.

CASA has advised that, in making changes to CAO 95.55 last year, proper industry and public consultation procedures were not followed. My understanding of the current situation is that the most recent amendments, made to the order on 19 May, address those items not properly covered by the consultation process and those paragraphs that were removed wrongly in the earlier amendment. These include ultralight flight in controlled airspace and the use of calibrated airspeed as the unit of measurement for stall speed.

The Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association has written to MPs and senators asserting that aircraft registered as ultralights face different operating restrictions from aircraft on the general register. They claim that every detail of the aircraft is identical, but they have not told senators the full story. What they have not told you is that ultralight pilots are subject to less rigorous licensing standards than pilots generally. They are subject to less rigorous medical requirements and aircraft registered as ultralights have lower maintenance requirements than aircraft on the VH register.

The opposition says that there was no consultation for these amendments. In fact, the Office of Regulation Review advised that a regulation impact statement was not necessary as the amendments are of a minor or machinery nature and do not involve policy changes. I feel that is very relevant to the arguments which you were putting, Senator. The motion to disallow the amendments appears to be based on the assumption that indicated airspeed should be used instead of calibrated airspeed. This assumption is completely flawed. In fact, the amendment corrects an error which CASA made when it amended CAO 95.55 in October 1998. The October amendments changed the stall speed limit from 40 knots calibrated airspeed to 45 knots. The October amendments erroneously omitted to state that the unit in which the stall speed is measured is calibrated airspeed. The amendments correct that error.

An attempt to disallow these amendments is an attempt to perpetrate a legislative error. It was not an intended error; it was a legislative error. There are two ways of measuring airspeed. Indicated airspeed is the raw reading obtained from the aircraft sensors. Calibrated airspeed corrects this reading for instrument errors and position errors. In other words, if you want an accurate representation of the aircraft airspeed, you have to use the calibrated airspeed. Anyone with a technical backgroundâwhich I do not claim to have, but my advice is of that natureâwho claims that CASA meant that stall speed should be measured using indicated airspeed is being deceptive. CASA consistently uses calibrated airspeed as the unit of measurement for stall speed. What happened in October was an error, a regrettable oversight. I have that from time to time in my portfolio. So I have some sympathy for CASA and for the transport portfolio.

Australian legislation has consistently used calibrated airspeed as the stall speed unit. For example, CAO 101.55, which up to October 1998 regulated the stall speed limits of ultralights, used the CAS unit. CAO 101.28, which governs the airworthiness of certification requirements for amateur built aircraft, also regulates stall speed limits using the CAS unit. That is why the federal aviation regulationsâthe air safety legislation of the United Statesâuse calibrated airspeed as the stall speed unit. That is why the joint aviation authorities which set aviation standards for the major European states use calibrated airspeed as the stall speed unit.

If these amendments are disallowed, the Senate will be signalling that it wants Australia's aviation safety legislation to be inconsistent with that of the major aviation states such as the United States, United Kingdom, France and Germany. I cannot believe that the opposition is intending that. I urge you to vote against this misguided motion to disallow commonsense amendments to CAO 95.55. I remind you that the amendments clarify that stall speeds should be measured in calibrated airspeed. They ensure that Australia's aviation safety regulations are consistent with international standards.

A new notice of proposed rule makingâNPRMâon sport aviation will be issued in October 1999. This will cover pilot standards, maintainer standards and definitions of ultralight aircraft and give all interested parties an opportunity to state their positions. CASA is putting in place a new consultation process which will prevent such a situation from happening in the future and ensure that all legislative change will be covered by the formal notice of proposed rule making process.

In conclusion, I suggest that the appropriate process to ensure that Australian regulations governing sport aviation operations are harmonised and ensure safety standards that are equal to the best global standards is to follow the NPRM process. As CASA will issue the NPRM in October, all parties will be able to fully participate in the regulation making process ensuring a fair and balanced outcome.

talk.start.para: âI thank the minister for her comments and for displaying the same expertise in this matter as I have. In these matters, we all rely on the advice we have in the positions that we take. In relation to the argument about the use of the factor calibrated airspeed, I am advised that the new Australian experimental category does not in fact call for calibrated airspeed. So it seems that there is a discrepancy between the regulation in this case and the Australian experimental category. I am also advised that the Canadian standard for ultralights, which I am told is TP 10141E, uses indicated airspeed not calibrated airspeed. So it is not as if there is a common international approach with which we are out of step but rather some differences.

speech.para: I stress that there was a strong view that proper consultation had not taken place and that for that reason the opposition was of the view that it would be better that that take place before these changes are implemented, given what we were advised will be the significant implications of the measures on the community affected, that is, the ultralight community.

It has been argued to usâand I am not in a position where I have statistics to contest thisâthat for ultralight pilots it is true that the requirements as to training and qualification are less but that there is formalised training of ultralight pilots, which was introduced in the mid-1980s, and that the accident rate has steadily improved until it is on par with general aviation. One always likes to see improvement and perfection in aviationâI guess we are entitled to seek thatâbut we would expect that in many cases that is not going to be achieved, due to factors such as weather and human error.

It is argued by the Ultralight Federation that current ultralight accident statistics show that stalling as a causal factor is virtually a non-event. Therefore, if we do in fact disallow this regulation we are not blocking a measure which has, on the face of it, significant short-term consequences. If indeed, as the minister says, there is a process about to commence in relation to the review of all regulations, one would have thought that this matter could be rolled into that and dealt with at the same timeâor indeed, if there is some other need to process it, this matter could be dealt with expeditiously before that matter commences. There have been on the record now a number of opinions from the affected aviation community, and the opinion of the department has been laid out before the parliament. One would have thought that in this case a disallowance might proceed without causing any undue problems.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI do not know that I am helping you very much, but you mentioned experimental aircraft, and I am informed that by definition experimental aircraft do not have specified standards. And you are right in your comments about Canada using IAS, but the United States, France, UK, Italy, Germany, et cetera use the CAS unit, and it would seem very sensible that Australia should harmonise with the major aviation nations, which are united in their acceptance of CAS. talk.start.para: âI move business of the Senate motion No. 2, standing in my name:

speech.para: Thatâ

(1) The Senate directs that each senator provide to the President, and the President present to the Senate, on or before the tenth day of sitting after the passage of this resolution, a certification, signed by the senator, that the senator is, to the best of the senator's knowledge, qualified to serve in the Senate under section 44 of the Constitution, together with documentary proof that the senator is not subject to the disability referred to in paragraph 44(i) of the Constitution.
(2) For the purpose of paragraph (1), the documentary proof is:

(a) a copy of a birth certificate indicating that the senator was born in Australia and a certification signed by the senator that the senator has not subsequently been a citizen of another country; or

(b) if the senator was not born in Australia or has ever been a citizen of another country, documentation indicating that the senator has taken all reasonable steps to renounce any foreign nationality or citizenship.

One man's loss is another man's gain, as the saying goes. I am standing here today because of another person's misfortune, that person being Heather Hill. Heather Hill has unfortunately been the first senator-elect to be disqualified by the High Court, for the sin of not renouncing her British citizenship before nominating for the 1998 federal election. It is ironic that Heather Hill was deemed to have an allegiance to a foreign power even though she has lived here most of her life and her husband and children are Australian. Despite her many public affirmations of patriotism and loyalty to this country, she was disqualified.

It would appear by their actions that some members of the federal parliament have satisfied the letter of the law in regard to section 44(i) and so in fond theory are loyal and patriotic, but in practice their actions would appear to undermine our Constitution, our national sovereignty and the integrity of our federal system of government. Yet they have not been challenged under section 44.

I do not blame the High Court for finding that Britain is now a foreign power, although I was surprised at the court's decision; I blame the Labor Party for passing the Australia Act in 1986 and I blame the coalition for not repealing the Australia Act when it had the chance to do so. There are people who caused Heather Hill to lose her seat; it was not the High Court, which was only fulfilling its constitutional role. But I say to those people who tried to knock One Nation out of the Senate that they have failed. I say to those people who tried to knock Heather Hill out of politics that they also have failed. I am pleased to say that not only is Heather Hill present in this place today to witness this historic event but she will continue to play an important role in Australian politics for the foreseeable future. To those people who targeted Heather Hill while ignoring the other politicians suspected of ineligibility I say that they are hypocrites. Actions such as this often have unforeseen consequences, and I am sure that the people who orchestrated the removal of Heather Hill would not have foreseen the events that may be precipitated by the moving of this motion today.

From time to time, the qualifications and eligibility of various members of the House of Representatives and the Senate to serve have been questioned. The High Court has decided that Britain is now a foreign power. As a result of that decision, people believe that there have been in the past members of the federal parliament who sat while ineligible, and people believe that there may be members and senators who are now sitting while ineligible. This has resulted in considerable consternation and frustration, as many people regard the practice of politicians sitting in the federal parliament while ineligible to be a flouting of our Constitution.

The only way a member of the public can pursue the matter is to challenge the eligibility of the person in the High Court, but the cost in terms of time and money is large, and very few people to date have exercised this option. There is another way to challenge the eligibility of a senator to serve that does not involve the courts, results in a minimum cost and does not take much time, that is, by moving a motion concerning their qualification to serve under section 58 of the standing orders of the Senate. Heather Hill ran foul of section 44 of the Constitution and paid the price. Now it is time for the senators who swore allegiance to Australia on 9 August and those senators already sworn in to demonstrate to the Australian people that we are one nation with one set of rules for all. This motion must take precedence over government and general business of the day and must be either agreed to by the Senate or fail. If the Senate agrees to this motion, then the Australian people will know that all senators are qualified for service under section 44(1) of our Constitution for the first time in Australia's history. If the Senate disagrees with this motion, then suspicion and acrimony can only increase. Those senators who oppose this motionâand I sincerely hope that there will not be anyâobviously have something to hide and will have to answer to the Australian people.

talk.start.para: âThe Labor opposition will be opposing the motion that has been moved by Senator Harris. We will not be playing One Nation's games in this chamber on this occasion orâlet me say through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to Senator Harrisâon any other occasion. We have a situation here where, if the One Nation party has any evidence that any senator in this chamber is incapable of holding office as a senator by virtue of disqualification under section 44 of the Constitution, then someone has to put up. Let us have the evidence. If they have the evidence, a senator or senators can be challenged through the appropriate channels. That can be done by any Australian citizen. If they do not have the evidence, as far as the opposition is concerned there is no issue.

speech.para: Of course we would acknowledge that all senators are bound by both the Constitution and the electoral laws in this regard. I think that senators on all sides of the chamber take these laws very seriouslyâthey take these obligations very seriously. I certainly can say that we do in the Labor Party. I have no doubt that other political parties and other senators represented in this chamber do also.

Apparently, a One Nation candidate did not take these matters seriously and apparently the One Nation party feels on this issue that it has been unfairly singled out. The truth of the matter is that it is not the first at all. As we know, in Australian politics those are the breaks. If you fail to do your homeworkâas is the case with Ms Hillâyou make a mistakeâa big oneâand you get caught out, tough. That is the way it works. There have been enough experiences and enough examples in this country over recent years for any candidate to take these matters very seriously indeed.

We will have no part of what I think is a pretty half-baked, dubious and perhaps ill-conceived procedural device that is proposed today. The fact is that a member of the One Nation party and a member of the staff of the new One Nation senator, Senator Harris, was challenged about her compliance with section 44 of the Constitution. Those are the facts. That challenge was upheld by the High Court. Apparently, Ms Hill is unhappy about that. Senator Harris is absolutely delirious, because it is not as if he stood aside to allow Ms Hill to come back into the chamber after these matters had been regularised.

talk.start.para: âNo, definitely not.

âSenator Ray, in a serious interjection, agrees with me on that important point. But, does that give Ms Hill and Senator Harris, her unlikely boss, the right to come into this chamber with a motion like this and effectively accuse every other senator of the same offence until they prove their innocence on this issue? That is what this motion doesâguilty until proven inno cent on this particular issue. I do not think it does give Ms Hill and Senator Harris that right. It is absolutely outrageous for Senator Harris and the party that he represents to seek to abuse the procedures of this place just to vent Ms Hill's spleen.

speech.para: It is a bit of a nerve to proceed with a motion like this when only last week in the Queensland Supreme Court we had Justice Roslyn Atkinson say this about the 1997 decision by the Queensland Electoral Commission to register the One Nation party and its validity:
After reviewing the decision of the Commission, I am satisfied that the decision to register Pauline Hanson's One Nation under the Electoral Act 1992 was induced by fraud or misrepresentation.

That was Judge Atkinson's judgment. We have the Queensland Supreme Court ruling that the One Nation registration was induced by fraud or misrepresentation. Perhaps it may be just as reasonable to have a motion here asking Senator Harris to explain his party's actions. But that would not be appropriate, in my view. The only explaining to do is what Senator Harris has to explain to Ms Hillâwhy he has the seat and she does not have the seat; why he decided, after Ms Hill's eligibility had been regularised, to sit on.

We have a real little internal dog fight going on here, and the opposition is not going to have any part of that sort of stuntâand it has been a stunt from the very beginning. Who could forget the dramatic press conference that was called by the newly appointed Senator Harris on the day that senators were sworn in? There they were up in the press gallery holding their breath and wondering what the dramatic announcement was going to be. Do you know what it was? That Senator Harris was going to move this motion in the Senate. Hold the front page! What a dramatic development: a new Senator is going to move a motion in the Senate and the Senate is going to determine what its view might be on this particular matter!

We know that Senator Harris has had his arm twisted up behind his back by the aggrieved Ms Hill. We know that Ms Hill wants Senator Harris's seat. We know that Senator Harris has decided to stick in and not budge. He will be in here like a barnacle as long as he can, and Ms Hill can like it or lump it. Everyone knows that is the case. Senator Harris ought to do a little better in using the time he has in this place on behalf of the people that he now represents. He could do a lot better than just becoming a mouthpiece for his staffer, Ms Hill, who has forced him to take this particular action. He could do an awful lot better than lending his name to stunts like this. As far as the opposition is concerned, we will have no part of it on this or any other occasion.

talk.start.para: âI speak on behalf of the government on this motion and say that the government will not have any part of this stunt, either. There is a considerable degree of history to this whole issue. It is a shame that Senator Harris comes in here clearly without any knowledge of that history. That is not to be harsh on Senator Harris, but I would have thought that, when he raises matters such as this, it would rest with him to find out what it is all about. The Constitution provides very clearly:

speech.para: Any person whoâ
(i) Is under any acknowledgment of allegiance, obedience, or adherence to a foreign power . . . or is a subject or a citizen of a foreign power . . .

is disqualified from being chosen or of sitting as a member of parliament. It is crystal clear. Senator Harris mentioned in his contribution to the Senate that Mrs Hill's misfortune is his good fortune. In response to Senator Harris's statement about misfortune, I have to say that I do not believe it is any misfortune at all. It is purely and simply an inability to read the documentation that is provided to every candidate prior to nomination for the election.

If there is somehow a misfortune about someone being disqualified prior to entry, think what a gross misfortune it must be to people like former Senator Robert Wood, an Independent New South Wales senator, who was here for some time and then ruled ineligible. Look at someone like Phil Cleary from Victoria, who was in the House of Representatives for quite some time before being ruled ineligible. And there are other circumstances that surround all of these things. They were not looked upon as being someone who was unfortunate in the way in which they were removed from the parliament. It happened to be a crystal clear case of their not abiding by the Constitution.

I cannot understand why Senator Harris comes in here and says that there is something that we all have to prove when in fact we are the people who have read the documentation that has been provided and Mrs Hill has not. That just happens to be a statement of fact. It is not a case of trying to knock One Nation out of the Senate, as Senator Harris has claimed. Shock, horror: One Nation and its office holders have to abide by the law of the land, as does every other political party and individual. So why should Senator Harris be so indignant and come in here and say that we somehow have to prove that we are Australians? Such an attempt to cast a shadow over every senator and member really does warrant the old Australian phrase, `Either put up or zip up.' You cannot come in here and just lay accusations down without substantiating them.

It is not often that I have to agree with something that Senator Faulkner says, but the press conference announcing this motion was a reflection, sadly, of the way One Nation treats this parliament and treats the whole institution of government. To hear on the morning that Senator Harris was sworn in that there was going to be a press conference given by Senator Harris and Mrs Hill that day of `national importance' really did become a bit of a farce, to put it very politely. There is nothing of national importance in this at all. So far as the present constitutional rule in section 44(i) is concerned, the government thinks the constitutional and statutory framework is quite satisfactory to ensure that people do not stand for election if they are disqualified. So what is the problem that Senator Harris has got? The government believes that the Constitution and the Commonwealth laws already provide an adequate framework for ensuring that members of the Commonwealth parliament are not disqualified under that section of the Constitution.

The law which applies to dual citizenship of members of parliament is perfectly clear. The Australian Electoral Commission, as I said before, gives candidates plenty of warning about it, and it is absurd for One Nation, for Mrs Hill or for Senator Harrisâand I am sure, as is the opposition, that this all comes from Mrs Hill and not from Senator Harrisâto say that they are incapable of heeding all the warnings and therefore they have to somehow be forgiven. Then to come in here and to make a proposal that people prove they are not citizens of a foreign country is even more outrageous. What we would do there is actually reverse the onus of proof. What is Senator Harris trying to do? I think it is quite bizarre.

The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 sets out the qualifications which candidates for election to the Commonwealth parliament must satisfy. The act requires candidates for election to the Senate and the House of Representatives to consider whether they are qualified to be elected. I want to state quite clearly what the process is. When a person is nominated for election to the parliament, the person must declare in the nomination paper that he or she is qualified under the Constitution and the laws of the Commonwealth to be elected. That is the candidate's responsibility and nobody else's. The finger cannot be pointed at anybody else saying, `They didn't do it.' If a person is disqualified, it is the person who signed the nomination form who simply has to point the finger back at themselves and say, `I didn't do it.'

The Australian Electoral Commission provides an information kit to candidates for election. Let us talk specifically about the election of 1998, last year, when Mrs Hill was supposedly elected. The kit for that federal election drew candidates' attention to the disqualification in section 44(i) of the Constitution and it informed candidates that dual citizenship could be a ground for disqualification if candidates had not taken all reasonable steps to renounce dual citizenship before nomination. The kit included advice on renunciation procedures for various countries, including the United Kingdom. So there is hardly any claim that anyone can make who has got half a wit about them that they were unprepared or given insufficient or inadequate information. There is already an adequate mechanism for ensuring that candidates satisfy the requirements for eligibility. It directs candidates' attention to this issue and requires them to consider whether they meet statutory and constitutional qualifications. If the candidate does not do that, that is not the fault of the Senate. These are matters that, without question, are best considered by the candidates themselves, as it is only they who possess the information that is required to be put on the nomination form and it is only they who sign that nomination form.

The election of a person who is disqualified from being elected because of section 44(i) of the Constitution can also be challenged in court proceedings, as has now been demonstrated by Mrs Hill's case. So there is no point in crying foul after the event. Therefore, the government considers that these mechanisms ensure that dual citizenship issues arising in relation to members of parliament can be dealt with adequately and it does not believe that any parliamentary surveillance is necessary or that any stunts are necessary. Let us face it: that is all that this is. This is purely and simply yet again another One Nation publicity stunt, nothing more and nothing less. It is totally and utterly unnecessary and is just simply wasting the time of the Senate.

talk.start.para: âThe nub of the problem with Senator Harris's motion is that it really reverses the onus of proof; that is what is wrong with it. But I must say that in some sense, as he is representing such a xenophobic party, to see him have the broadness of mind to try to introduce the French judicial system into Australia or into the Senate's procedures is at least refreshing. One of the more intriguing parts I have found, from listening to the press conference the other day, is that Senator Harris and his staff member have a secret list. They waved the list around and said, `Here is a list of suspects.' The press asked them to table the list of suspects but they did not. I must say that I thought I had gone in a time machine back 45 or 50 years and was listening to the junior senator from Wisconsin, who also had a variety of secret lists. That is really the point: if Senator Harris has suspects, he should name them.

speech.para: Senator Harris, if you think there is a senator sitting around here or a member of the House of Representatives who is not properly qualified, name them. Put your finger in the pencil grinder, have a go and name them! Of course, Senator Harris or any other Australian citizen can take the qualifications of a senator or a member to the Court of Disputed Returns. Indeed, Senator Harris has one other advantage: he can use this chamber to refer matters to the Court of Disputed Returns, not a right accorded to the average citizen. Indeed, this chamber at any stage can send a matter to the Court of Disputed Returns, notwithstanding anything that is in the Electoral Act that prescribes timing or in any other way restricts rights. It is an unrestricted right and it is a right that has been used in the past.

Senator Webster was sent off to the Court of Disputed Returns on a matter of office of profit under the Crown and Senator Woods was sent offâby me, as it happens, by way of a resolution but with the support of the Senateâbecause he was not an Australian citizen. Senator Ferris almost made it there. This place carried a conditional motion and Senator Ferrisâbasically, I think, on advice from some of us implicitlyâadopted the technique of resigning to get over the offence that may have occurred and then being reappointed.

So it is not unheard of for this chamber to refer a matter of qualification to the Court of Disputed Returns but it always does that on the basis of some evidenceâand we do not want to reverse the onus of proof. What next are we going to have to get up and declare? Are we all going to have to get up and declare our sexual preference, whether we are vegetarians, what our religious view is or whether we have ever once in our life imbibed a controlled substance?

talk.start.para: âYou didn't inhale.
âSounds like fun.

âIt is fun in some categories but not in others. The basic point is that we do not have to prove, other than by giving our word, that we are properly here. If we are improperly here, it is up to someone else to prove it. Not only is it up to someone else to prove it; they can put some of their money up to prove it, just to test themselves.

speech.para: I will tell you one thing that did not surprise me. Senator Faulkner alluded to the fact that if Senator Harris were fair dinkum about this he would step aside for Mrs Hill. Several journos rang me at the time this went to the court and I said, `I don't know what the result will be but I will bet you any money you like that, if Senator-elect Hill gets knocked out, the number two on the ticket will not stand aside.'

I can recall the Woods case in 1988-89. Unfortunately he was in this chamber when it went against him in an afternoon. It was 4 o'clock and he came across and said, `I'm sorry I lost the court case but the number two on the ticket will step aside and I will be back here Monday.' I said, `Good luck. I am really pleased for you, Robert.' I got to the Ansett lounge 20 minutes later and Irina Dunn had left three phone messages for me, as the minister in charge of parliamentary and ministerial services, wondering when she could move into her new office. I just said, `Thank you, Irina, for re-establishing my faith in human nature because for a while I was disillusioned.'

I am not critical of Senator Harris for not stepping aside for the disqualified Senator-elect Hill. I suspect that, frankly, he will be a better senator than Mrs Hill; I think he has probably got some better qualities than his current senior staffer. Nevertheless, Senator Harris, if you wanted to rectify this position overall, it would take just one page. Type it up or I will get it typed for you, if you like. Give me a copy of your letterheadâ`I, Senator Harris, resign'âand then the Queensland One Nation Party could send Senator-elect Hill down here because she would now be qualified.
Honourable senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âColleagues must understand that there may not be a state based One Nation Party but that, because of the federal registration rules, the federal party maintain their registration. But what all of this reflects is a lack of attention to detail, and in many ways it is just desserts. If One Nation take a simplistic view of politics and argue that there are simplistic solutions, then that is what One Nation live by. But that very simplicity means they cannot get their candidate properly qualified before a Senate election and they cannot properly register their political party before a state election and may, in the process, forfeit half a million dollars in public funding. That, if you like, is the penalty that applies to an amateur political party that prides itself on its amateurishness.
âIsn't it a company?
âAs Senator Sherry said, it is a company, and they simply have to pay the price for that. Senator Harris quoted himself from the press conference. Let me quote him again:

speech.para: Any senator who opposes my motionâand I obviously hope there will not be anyâis obviously trying to hide something and will have to answer to the press and the Australian people.

I have to say that that is a slimy tactic in this place. People will oppose motions. They are not trying to hide something. They oppose them out of principle; they oppose them because they think they are a stunt. It is very poor form to accuse senators in this place of voting against a motion because they are trying to hide something. It is simply not true. If you have to vote for every resolution that has this implicit blackmail in it, then we will have these stunts day in, day out.

I did watch that press conference, and I thought that we as senators were diminished by it. I thought it was a rather sad press conference. Apart from the build-up that was not delivered on, frankly I found it very sad to see a senator sitting there being interrupted and overridden by a staff member. Maybe in that one sense I am an elitist, but I do believe in the pre-eminence of the senator as opposed to the staffer. I hope that, within that, I accord a whole range of rights to staffers but not one of sitting at a press conference telling me what to do and correcting me in front of all those journos. That is not a very good look for the Senate, or for anyone else for that matter.

Let us get down to the nub of the problem. The nub of the problem is that Senator-elect Hill was disqualified. I do not think that Senator-elect Hill deliberately put herself at risk. I do not think she knew that you not only had to have Australian citizenship but also had to renounce. I do not think she knew that. I do not think she consciously kept her UK citizenship, but one of the questions that should be asked of someone who is so opposed to other people coming into this countryâand I have heard her being interviewed on this subjectâis: why didn't she take out citizenship? She was in this country for well over 20 years and qualified for citizenship for 20 years and did not take it out.

Why did she take out Australian citizenship? So she could run for the Ipswich seat in the state election. That is the only reason why. I know she was part of that unique band of people who were born in the UK and who still have voting rights within Australia, but it does not show much commitment that, when you are eligible to become an Australian citizen for more than 20 years, you only do so to run for parliament. Even so, I would not be critical except for the fact that we have heard a whole range of racist and xenophobic views out of the then Senator-elect Hillâcriticising others when she herself, the great patriot, would not take out citizenship for more than two decades.

As Senator Knowles indicated, following the Hill case the qualifications in terms of citizenship and renunciation are quite explicit. I would not even try to mislead the Senate to say that I was surprised by the 1992 decision on Clearyânot the office-for-profit part but the issue of citizenship and the renouncing of it. Since that became clear, both the Labor Party and the Liberal Party prior to every election meticulously go through all their candidates' biographies and check to see that they are qualified. I know that happens on both sides of politics. It is tedious and it is time consuming, but it is done so that we do not face these particular situations. That is something that One Nation is going to have to do on future occasions when it thinks it may have a successful candidate. The motion today is in part a bit of revenge and in part a bit of grandstanding, but it is flawed because it requires the reverse onus of proof.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on behalf of the Australian Democrats in relation to Senator Harris's motion, his first substantive motion that has been debated in this chamber. As I am sure all senators would know, the Democrats confronted One Nation fairly directly in a political sense leading up to, and as part of, the federal election campaign last year. The results having been declared and the new Senate having taken its place, I indicate on behalf of the Democrats that, given that this is the first substantive motion that the One Nation representative has moved, we are quite happy to consider everything that Senator Harris puts forward on its individual merits. Having done so with this motion, I concur with the comments of previous speakers. The Democrats do not believe this is a motion worthy of support. For reasons similar to those of others, it does in many ways put up a reverse onus of proof.

speech.para: The point that has not been made very much to date is that every senator who was elected to this placeâwhich is most of us in this chamber; I was an appointee, but most were electedâhas to sign on their nomination form that they are, to the best of their knowledge, qualified to serve in the Senate under section 44 of the Constitution. So they have already signed documentation indicating that they are qualified.

Heather Hill obviously signed the same piece of paper and was mistaken in her belief, which I assume, like Senator Ray, was a genuine belief. I do not think that anyone would have any motivation for deliberately trying to deceive in that regard, but it is difficult to believe, given the issues that have appeared many times over the last decade or soânot just Phil Cleary's case but also Senator Robert Woods' more specifically and a number of other High Court rulings in relation to dual citizenshipâthat people who thought they had a serious chance of being elected, and obviously Heather Hill was one of those, would not have been aware of that particular requirement, particularly given that her own citizenship was raised as an issue just a few months previously in the Queensland state election, which I well recall, being from that state.

Virtually every senator here has already signed a nomination form. Even those who are appointed, such as me, have to sign a piece of paper verifying that we are eligible to take up and to hold the office of senator. As others have said, it is clearly unnecessary to introduce a motion, virtually by way of a stunt, to affirm what all of us have already affirmed. It is unfortunate that One Nation has seen fit to cast aspersions on the eligibility of a number of parliamentarians without any proof whatsoever, beyond vaguely mentioning that some of them were born overseas or had parents who were born overseas or something like that. One Nation was quite happy to cast aspersions on a number of parliamentarians, including a couple of my Democrat colleagues. Yet, as Senator Ray said, a mechanism is available to us in this place whereby we do not have to go through the expense of High Court challenges. We can raise these matters in this chamber. The chamber can then decide whether or not to refer a matterâwhich, as Senator Ray outlined, has been done a number of times in the past.

I would assume that, before the Senate would consider seriously any such suggestion, the crucial requirement would be that evidence be put forward that seeks to demonstrate some indication of doubt about the eligibility of a particular senator. Clearly, despite a willingness to make vague assertions that some people might not be eligible orâas Senator Harris said in his contribution todayâthat anyone who votes against this motion must have something to hide, despite these very general attempts to blacken everybody, no attempt whatsoever has been made to put forward even the vaguest evidence. Until evidence is put forward in relation to any senator, I am certainly not particularly interested in the Senate spending any time on a measure such as this.

This measure is not necessary. Plenty of other processes are already in place. If it is not a stunt, this is an attempt at a final dummy spit by Heather Hill as a consequence of her disqualification. I can understand her annoyance. I imagine that it would be rather annoying to experience that. I do not blame her for feeling a bit annoyed because I suspect I would be annoyed as well in that situation. I met Robert Woods when, some time down the track, as some people may not know, he drifted into the Democrats. He was a bit irritated about what happened to him tooâand he was probably even more irritated that he did not get his seat back afterwards. These things happen.

It is ironic that a party like One Nationâwhich, more than most, likes to go on about the sanctity of the Constitution and our founding fathers and the importance of upholding the Constitutionâshould make such complaints about the High Court upholding a basic requirement of the Constitution. While Senator Ray said he would not like to predict what the outcome of the High Court might have been in relation to this, I would certainly have been extremely surprised if there was any outcome other than the one that occurred.

From the Democrats' point of view, we do not believe this motion is necessary. I should probably not impugn too nastily what Senator Harris's motives might have been in bringing it forward, but I suggest that, if One Nation does have evidence about the validity of any senators in relation to their requirements to serve in this place under the Constitution, it present that evidence to this chamber in a serious way. I will certainly happily consider it in that context, but not in a motion such as this.

talk.start.para: âAs I have told Senator Harris, I will not be supporting the motion for, amongst other things, the reasons that have been put by all the contributing senators who have so far opposed the motion. One of the problems is the reversal of the onus of proof. There is not a precedent for this sort of motion before the parliamentâor not one that I could find, anyway. I am concerned that it could be followed up by a wide variety of motions which require members of parliament to attest to their propriety without there having been any evidence that they had acted with impropriety. Surely that is not the way for us to proceed in a parliament in which, as has been said by previous speakers, members have been required to sign something to say that they have abided by constitutional requirements. In effect, through taking the oath or affirmation when entering this place, they have repeated the assurance that they have been properly elected.

speech.para: However, I draw to the chamber's attention the need for us to deal with this matter. There seems to be almost a herd instinct to avoid changing parts of constitutions which can lead, inadvertently or otherwise, to members of parliament being trapped. The Tasmanian constitution act requires amending as it has a glitch in it. Several MPs have fallen prey to that. They have had to get retrospective legislation through the parliamentâa very unseemly way of proceedingâto have their seats validated. We are not in too different a situation here. Both Senate and joint committees have recommended to parliament that section 44 be amended.

Senators will be aware that I have legislation before the Senate now to give the opportunity to the people of Australia to amend the Constitution so that the something like seven million Australians who are currently denied the right to stand for parliament would gain that right. I will be lobbying the Senate to allow that referendum opportunity. It is simply not good enough for the parliament to allow the matter to drift. In that sense, the positive follow-through I can give to Senator Harris is that I will be pushing to have that legislation, which was debated last November, brought before the Senate again for debate in the near futureâand I will need the good offices of the Labor Party for thatâso that we can get a resolution on it. I would have liked the matter put to the people at the 6 November referendum but, if not then, it should be at the next election. That said, I will not be supporting the motion but I think action is needed and, in that sense, Senator Harris has brought before the chamber a matter which we cannot put to rest at this moment and in this way.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 7.30 p.m.

talk.start.para: âIt was not my intention to speak on this motion, at least initially, until I became somewhat concerned by the approach adopted by the One Nation Party in identifying and attempting to infer some wrongdoing by those of us not born in Australia. I am one of those people. Before I commence my contribution, I want to make a couple of comments about the issue of dual nationality and alleged allegiance to a foreign power.

speech.para: This concept is very outdated and outmoded in a modern world. From my knowledge of history, which is an interest of mine, the issue of dual nationality is a medieval concept that derived, at least initially, from the time when William the Conqueror, as he is known, who was the Duke of Normandy, invaded England. He had kingship in his own right of what was then England and he held dukeship in Normandy, owing allegiance to the king of France. That is where the concept of dual nationality originally arose. As a consequence of the various struggles that took place between the English and the French crown, the custom and practice emerged in British common law that a citizen of England and, ultimately, the United Kingdom could not owe allegiance to any other crown.

I think the concept is outmoded and outdated. Irrespective of whether a public official elected to this place is born in Australia or has dual nationality, the theory is that they have some split allegiance. They are considered to have some allegiance to a foreign power because of where they were born and, therefore, they are presumably some sort of national security risk. The concept is totally outmoded and irrelevant in the modern world and should not exist. Nevertheless, the High Court, in its latest decision in respect of senator-elect Hill, has made three decisions on this issue. The law is now very clear in respect of dual nationality.
In respect of my own circumstances, I was born in England at Kingston-on-Thames on 19 November 1955.

talk.start.para: âA good year.

âIt was a good year. My mother was English and my father was Australian. My father was working in England at the time. Unfortunately, I came along at the wrong time because my father had wanted to return to Australia in the earlier part of 1955. With my mother expecting me, they had to postpone the trip and set sail about six months after I was born. So I have grown up in Australia and spent most of my life in Tasmania, where my father settled in late 1956. I do not think one could detect much of an English accent; perhaps there is a slight Tasmanian accent.

speech.para: I have lived all my life here. I have lived longer in Australia than my brother. He was born two years later. I do not consider myself any less Australian than my brother. On reaching the age of 18, I took out Australian citizenship, not because I was interested in standing for parliament at that time but because I believed I was an Australian through and through and that part of the commitment to your country involves taking out Australian citizenship. In 1990, I was elected to the Senate.

In 1992, there was a case involving a member of the other place, Mr Cleary, who was elected to the seat of former Prime Minister Bob Hawke. In the case of Mr Cleary, I do not believe it was the issue of dual nationality; I think it was office of profit under the crown. There were a number of other candidates who the High Court determined had dual nationality. The High Court made it very clear in 1992 that if you held dual nationality and it were practical to do so, you had to take every reasonable step to renounce the citizenship of the country in which you were born if that country had that provision within its constitution or law.

So there were quite a number of us in late 1992 who, after that High Court decision, appeared to have dual citizenship. I did not realise that I was still a citizen of the United Kingdom, having taken out Australian citizenship. Nevertheless, that is what the High Court determined. I went down to the British High Commission and made some inquiries about renunciation. Apparently, there is an act of British parliament for the renunciation of UK citizenship. I picked up the form and filled it in. I think I paid $50. It has recently gone up somewhat, as I understand it. I understand that it is now about $250. Obviously, there has been a bit of a money making exercise occurring with the dual citizenship decisions.

talk.start.para: âMrs Thatcher introduced it.

âIt was probably Margaret Thatcher. Certainly it is not a bad money-spinner for the British High Commission with the number of people who have been renouncing their British citizenship recently, but it was only $50 back at the end of 1992. Channel Nine were quite interested in a number of us and they got me on film carrying out my renunciation. As I say, that happened to quite a number of people as a result of the Cleary case that was determined before the High Court in 1992. I have subsequently been re-elected as a senator and I am very confident that I qualify.

speech.para: I take objection to the way in which this issue has been promoted by One Nation. My name, along with a number of others, has been put into press releases inferring that we have done something wrong, when I certainly have not, and I am certainly not aware of any of my other parliamentary colleagues having done anything wrong.

As a result of the 1992 High Court decision the Australian Labor Party put into place effective mechanisms to ensure that, firstly, we were Australian citizens and, secondly, we did not hold dual citizenship, amongst a range of other criteria to be satisfied in order to qualify for preselection for the Australian Labor Party. I am aware that the Liberal Party put similar mechanisms in place at that time. I noticed that when I last stood for election, the Australian Electoral Commission had improved their declaration and made the position very clear as a result of that High Court case in 1992. If you are standing for parliament, if you have an effective political organisation run by competent operators, and if you bother to read the nomination forms and the kit that comes with it, it is not as though you would not know that this is the process.

As I said in my introductory remarks, I think the concept of dual nationality and somehow owing allegiance to a foreign power is an outmoded concept in the modern world. To that extent, I understand the disappoint ment that senator-elect Hill has gone through. But that can not excuse the sheer incompetence of the One Nation leadership in the way that they handled their preselection processes. Any organisation that is structured in the way that One Nation isâand we have had some recent exposure of the way in which One Nation is structured and operated in Queensland, and our leader, Senator Faulkner, referred to thatâwhere a political party, or rather a political company, is so structured that it is run by the three shareholdersâMr Oldfield, Mr Ettridge and Ms Hansonâmust be considered incompetent. They are the three that run the show, that run the company, that run the political partyâthe triumvirate that took it upon itself to make sure that it had total control and total power over One Nation. As I say, that has been reinforced by the recent decision of the Queensland Supreme CourtâI think it wasâin respect to its illegal registration.

Over the past couple of years, Mr Oldfield and Mr Ettridge have touted themselves as political Machiavellis, but they fell down. Given the likelihood of the election of a One Nation Senate candidate in the polling at the time, I am sure that this triumvirate determined, or had a very significant say, in who the One Nation candidate was going to be to head the Senate ticket in Queensland. It just basically came down to incompetence.

I have some sympathy for senator-elect Hill, who obviously put her trust in this triumvirate, but the sheer incompetence of these three should be noted. Not only did they organise the structure of the party so that they ran the whole show, but they also openly boasted about their intention to operate it as a three-person operation and they put up the pretence that it was a democratic organisation. So really, the motion we have before us today, obviously, as all the other speakers have said, is offensive in the sense that it infers that a number of usâand I am amongst those who were born overseasâhave done something wrong when we have not really. The blame should be sheeted home to the basic incompetence of the three who formed the leadership of the One Nation party.

I concur with the comments made by other contributors in this debate. There are other mechanisms for dealing with this matter, by a resolution of the Senate and referral of any one of us to the High Court. Regrettably for senator-elect Hill, she got caught out, as I say, by the lack of professionalism of the leadership of One Nation. They boasted about how good they were at the political process and that has now caught up with them.

There is one other point I would like to make. In respect of senator-elect Hill, it was not as though this issue has only been a recent matter. One Nation says that they are innocent, that this is a grand conspiracy by the major parties, that the major parties are ganging up against them. Poor One Nation! Poor senator-elect Hill! That is the nature of the theme that, in part, One Nation has been running in respect to this issue and it is simply not true.

The previous decision in the Wood case and the previous decision in respect of candidates in the Cleary matterâboth went before the High Courtâwere well known and well publicised at the time. They were well publicised subsequently by the Electoral Commission and were available for any candidate to peruse had they bothered to read the material. Despite this having some publicity in the Queensland state election where senator-elect Hill was a candidate, the triumvirate Oldfield, Ettridge and Hanson apparently completely ignored it all. I did not realise until I made some inquiries today that senator-elect Hill was not even an Australian citizen. I can understand someone not being aware of renunciation procedures, but when you have been living in this country for a long timeâ20 yearsâboasting about your Australian nationalism, indeed openly promoting your attitude to migrants and your opposition to migration into this country, particularly from Asia, making that one of the central planks of your platform in the lead-up to an election and declaring just how Australian Australians should be, surely you should have Australian citizenship if you are running for election for any form of office in this country. Apparently, senator-elect Hill did not even qualify for that very basic and fundamental prerequisite of Australian citizenship.

I conclude on the point that Senator Brown raised in the proposition that he has put forward of a referendum in respect of a question that would permit any person resident in Australia to run for political office. In other words, you could have been born overseas, not be an Australian citizen, and, if you hold dual citizenship, it should not matter. That is the proposition that Senator Brown wants to put to a referendum. I would put to Senator Harris: what would One Nation's position be on such a question? Are One Nation willing to endorse the proposition that anyone who is resident in Australiaâregardless of nationality, regardless of citizenship or whether they hold dual citizenshipâshould be able to run for political office in this country? I would be interested to know what One Nation's attitude would be to such a proposition. I suspect that, six months ago, they would have been vehemently opposed to such a proposition. They would have argued that you had to be an Australian citizen, that you could not hold dual nationality, that you had to be dinky-di Aussie in order to stand for political office. That is what I think the position would have been six months ago. It may have changed in light of senator-elect Hill's experiences.

Finally, I endorse the contributions of all the other senators who have spoken on this matter. I add that the triumvirate that run the so-called political party of One Nation have to take responsibility for this. They decided to run it as a company; they decided that they were the fountain of all political knowledge. They openly boasted of that, yet they failed in what is a very basic prerequisite in politicsâthat is, to at least know whether your candidates are eligible to run for office or not. And it is not as though they were not warned. I also take exception to the type of material that we have seen circulated recently, in which it is inferred that those amongst us who were born overseas have in some way done something wrong when we have not. My position is clear. It is on the public record. It has been on the public record since the end of 1992 and it attracted some publicity at that time. I am very confident that I have done the right thing by section 44. For the reasons that I have outlined and all the other reasons that have been spoken of in this chamber, I do not believe we should be supporting the proposition as moved by Senator Harris on behalf of One Nation.

talk.start.para: âMr Acting Deputy President, it will not come as any surprise to you or anyone else in this chamber that I will be opposing this motion very vigorously. Two weeks ago, when this matter was of historical momentâyou may remember the press conferenceâI was actually quite angry about what was going on and about the discriminatory practices of a certain political party being brought into a chamber such as this. Is there discrimination? I invite you to look at paragraph 2(a) and paragraph 2(b) of the motion. Can you see how this applies differently to those of us who were born in another country? If a motion such as this were carried, Australia would be a laughing stock to the rest of the world. I am very pleased that colleagues from all political parties have rejected this proposition. It will be interesting to hear the responses that will come back if the mover of the motion cares to respond to the argument that is being put forward.

speech.para: I was angry two weeks ago, but I am actually very sorry for the individuals now. I am very sorry that they are proceeding and persisting down this path. There is obviously something lacking if they continue to do so. They are making idiots of themselves. They are actually making gooses of themselves.

talk.start.para: âGeese!

âNo; gooses, Senator. I am sticking to that. I will quote later on from a press release that was issued by the One Nation Party on 25 Juneâa matter which I have spoken about in this place once beforeâheaded, `Good for the goose and good for the gander'. If you say `geese', you are actually adding to it. `Gooses' it is going to be for the remainder of this particular speech.

speech.para: I feel sorry that in the two weeks that have elapsed the mover of the motion and the persons behind him have not done a little bit of research. They have not found out that this matter of the Constitution and its application is not a new matter at all. I got a mention in the press statement that I have just alluded to. They spelt my name wrongly and I am cranky about that. I spoke in this place and referred to some of the historical developments that previous speakers have referred to this afternoon. One was the case of former Senator Wood who was replaced by Senator Dunn. Those cases focused the minds of 76 senators and that of our political parties on the necessities of standing for the very high office that we hold. That was way back in 1988, probably before she had learned to fry fish and chips, probably before she had any sort of interest in politics, other than the bitterness and the bile that has been building over 30 years.

It was brought more into focus in 1992 with Phil Cleary, that great football commentator. He is probably more suited to that role than the role he carried out in the parliamentâa nice bloke who is very self-opinionated. His case went off to the High Court of Australia. Irrespective of the results one way or another, we as members of parliament had an interest in that case. We particularly followed the judgment. Our political fortunes ride on decisions like that, so we become very aware of decisions of the High Court and the qualifications for office.

My first experience with it, which I alluded to in the speech I made on 25 June, was way back during the 1987 campaign when a certain lawyer in Sydney drew attention to the fact that he was going to take us all to the High Courtâ`us all' being the senators of the day. My political party, the Australian Labor Party, took notice of what was going on. They took steps then to alert each and every one of us who were serving in parliament at that pointâthis is going back 12 yearsâthat we should get our affairs in order to make sure we were qualified to remain in office and, equally importantly, for those who were contesting the following election in 1990, to get our affairs in order if we were born in another country or could be shown to hold allegiance to another power.

On our side of the parliament we had Lionel Bowen as the Attorney-Generalâthe great Lionel Bowen, whose evidence we heard last week at a Senate committee, and it was a thrill to see him again. He provided advice not only to members on this side of the chamberâwe were on that side of the chamber at that particular timeâbut to a range of members of parliament who were not born in Australia. This is going way, way back. In my case, I have since contested the 1990 election and got re-elected and I contested the 1996 election and got re-elected. Nobody challenged in the High Court whether or not I was qualified to hold office or that I had the right to it. I still have the right to it in this chamber. I was warned on 25 June this year in a press statement headed `Good for the gooseâgood for the gander'.

We can all be a bit self-deprecating from time to time, but it is unusual that we put it in print to this extent. On this occasion, the goose was the leadership of One Nation, probably the failed candidate who made a goose of herself by nominating and not finding out what the rules were, and more importantly, not finding out what the laws were. The press release states:
